Det ligner en virkelighedsvækkelse, der i øjeblikket skyller ind over rådhuset. Det er nu nok nærmere valgkampstaktik forklædt som eftertænksomhed.

Venstre og Det Konservative Folkeparti er brudt ud af aftalen fra 2017 om, at ansvaret for 900 aarhusianske veje skal skubbes over på grundejerne. På teknokratisk kaldes det »nedklassificering« og »harmonisering«. På jævnt aarhusiansk: Politikerne sender regningen og besværet – men ikke friheden – videre til husejerne. Man kan også oversætte det til »en skævt fordelt ekstra skat«.

Det er ikke kun Aarhus, der har svaghed for den slags regnearks-fiduser. Også andre kommuner har været vilde med tricket – så vilde, at den daværende transportminister Hans Christian Schmidt (V) allerede i 2010 måtte hive i nødbremsen: Kommuner må ikke udlicitere asfalt bare for at redde en skrantende økonomi. Derfor er det også pudsigt, at Socialdemokratiet og SF’s første reaktion var et bekymret: »Jamen hvor skal pengene så komme fra?« Svaret blafrer stadig i vinden, omtrent lige så tungt og uklart som, hvad det vil koste af stoppe privatiseringsiveren. Nu er det op til en 10-dages forespørgsel at finde hoved og hale i tallene.

Vækkelsen rammer ikke kun vejene, men også gaderne. Især dem i midtbyen, hvor detailhandlen råber så højt om problemerne, at politikerne stimler sammen, som var det et regulært ophørsudsalg.

SF, Danmarksdemokraterne, Det Konservative Folkeparti og Socialdemokratiet fandt i denne uge sammen om et nyt udspil. Der skal oprettes et detailråd og det skal være nemmere at være håndværker og erhvervsdrivende i midtbyen. Forslaget indeholder også en forsøgsordning med aften- og natlevering af varer samt en analyse af detailhandelens vilkår i hver byrådsperiode for at kvalificere byrådets beslutninger.

Men konkurrencen om nu at være erhvervslivets bedste ven er hård. Venstre nåede nemlig et par dage forinden at præsentere sit eget katalog af gode hensigter. Partiet kræver »fakta før symbolpolitik«, »rimelige parkerings- og adgangsforhold« og »sommergågader med måde«.

På samme måde satte Bang rekord i bakgear, da han pludselig bremsede en forlængelse af Jægergårdsgade status som sommergågade med ensretninger og betonklodser. Det skete efter et døgn og tre henvendelser fra vrede butiksjere.

Indtil videre består aftalen om, at flere aarhusianere over det kommende år må overtage vejene. Det skaber ballade og usikkerhed, og for at understrege den aktuelle virkelighedsvækkelse, er det interessant at hæfte sig ved, hvad den konservative rådmand for teknik og miljø, Nicolaj Bang sagde til Stiften, da han og V-leder Christian Budde trak sig fra den aftale, som de ellers flere gange har bekræftet opbakningen til.

»Det blev vedtaget af nogle politikere, hvor størstedelen ikke sidder i byrådet længere. Til gengæld er det os, der står her nu, der har oplevet konsekvenserne, for vi får jævnligt henvendelser fra folk, der føler sig klemt i den her proces.«

Man kan håbe, at der ikke blot er tale om en midlertidig erkendelse på grund af valgkampen, men at den også vil præge byrådsarbejdet bagefter. For længe har praksisnær fornuft stået i skyggen af ideologi og symbolpolitiske markeringer. Og for længe har embedsværket formet virkelighedsopfattelsen gennem begreber, notater og slides. Men virkeligheden opleves bedst i live – ikke i en powerpoint.

Vi burde i grunden hylde politikere, der tør erkende, at der er blevet klogere. Hellere det end politikere, der stædigt holder fast i gamle beslutninger, der ikke er svaret på nutidens problemer. At der så lige op til valget den 18. november er så mange, der er blevet klogere, kan man tænke over.
eng_text:
It looks like a reality check that is currently washing over the city hall. It is now more likely an election campaign tactic disguised as thoughtfulness.

The Liberal Party and the Conservative People's Party have broken away from the agreement from 2017 that the responsibility for 900 Aarhus roads should be shifted onto the landowners. In technocratic terms, this is called "downgrading" and "harmonization". In plain Aarhusian terms: The politicians are passing the bill and the hassle - but not the freedom - on to the homeowners. It can also be translated as "an unevenly distributed extra tax".

It is not only Aarhus that has a weakness for this kind of spreadsheet scam. Other municipalities have also been crazy about the trick - so crazy that the then Minister of Transport Hans Christian Schmidt (V) had to pull the emergency brake as early as 2010: Municipalities are not allowed to outsource asphalt just to save an ailing economy. It is therefore also strange that the Social Democrats and the Social Democrats' first reaction was a worried: "Well, where will the money come from?" The answer is still fluttering in the wind, about as heavy and unclear as what it will cost to stop the privatization rush. Now it is up to a 10-day inquiry to find head and tail in the numbers.

The revival affects not only the roads, but also the streets. Especially those in the city center, where the retail trade is shouting so loudly about the problems that the politicians are crowding together as if it were a regular clearance sale.

This week, the Social Democrats, the Danish Democrats, the Conservative People's Party and the Social Democrats came together on a new proposal. A retail council is to be established and it is to be easier to be a craftsman and business owner in the city center. The proposal also includes a pilot scheme with evening and night delivery of goods as well as an analysis of the retail trade's conditions in each city council term in order to qualify the city council's decisions.

But the competition to be the best friend of the business community is fierce. A few days earlier, the Liberal Party had managed to present its own catalogue of good intentions. The party demands "facts before symbolic politics", "reasonable parking and access conditions" and "moderate summer pedestrian streets".

Similarly, Bang put a record in reverse gear when he suddenly put the brakes on an extension of Jægergårdsgade's status as a summer pedestrian street with one-way streets and concrete blocks. This happened after a day and three inquiries from angry shop owners.

For now, the agreement that more Aarhusians will have to take over the roads over the coming year remains in place. This is causing trouble and uncertainty, and to emphasize the current awakening to reality, it is interesting to note what the conservative councilor for technology and the environment, Nicolaj Bang, said to the Diocese when he and V-leader Christian Budde withdrew from the agreement, which they have otherwise confirmed their support for several times.

"It was adopted by some politicians, most of whom are no longer on the city council. On the other hand, it is we who are standing here now who have experienced the consequences, because we regularly receive inquiries from people who feel squeezed in this process."

One can hope that this is not just a temporary realization due to the election campaign, but that it will also influence the work of the city council afterwards. For too long, practical reason has been overshadowed by ideology and symbolic political markings. And for too long, the civil service has shaped the perception of reality through concepts, notes and slides. But reality is best experienced live – not in a PowerPoint.

We should basically pay tribute to politicians who dare to acknowledge that we have become wiser. Rather than politicians who stubbornly hold on to old decisions that are not the answer to today's problems. The fact that so many have become wiser just before the election on November 18th is something to think about.

Et spørgsmål om at nedklassificere omkring 900 offentlige veje til private fællesveje har udviklet sig til et større tema ved det kommende kommunalvalg.

For nylig trak Konservative og Venstre i Aarhus Byråd sig fra et budgetforlig om nedklassificeringen, der betyder, at utallige aarhusianske grundejere skal overtage omkostningerne ved at vedligeholde de veje, de bor på, fra kommunen.

Nu stempler en ny borgerliste ind i valgkampen, og borgerlistens navn siger alt om formålet med at stille op til kommunalvalget. Nej til privatisering af kommunale veje er stiftet af borgere, der ønsker at sikre, at »kommunale veje igen bliver et fælles ansvar.«

Den nye borgerliste har tilsluttet sig det borgerlige valgforbund i Aarhus bestående af Venstre, Konservative, Danmarksdemokraterne, Liberal Alliance og Dansk Folkeparti. Formålet er at stå samlet mod privatiseringen af vejene.

»Det her handler om, at vi gerne vil repræsentere ganske almindelige aarhusianere, som bliver ramt af beslutninger truffet langt fra virkeligheden. Vi vil gerne møde beslutningstagerne på deres egen bane, og det er i byrådet. Vi betaler som grundejere temmelig høje skatter, og vi synes det er urimeligt, at vi skal have sådan en negativ bonus oveni hovedet. Det kan i yderste konsekvens betyde, at nogle må gå fra hus og hjem,« siger borgerlistens spidskandidat, Steen Jørgensen.

Han bor i Brabrand og er til daglig studielektor i offentlig ret ved Aarhus Universitet.

En borgerliste er kendetegnet ved, at dens kandidater ikke repræsenterer et af de traditionelle landsdækkende partier og ikke har et ideologisk tilhørsforhold på landsplan. For at kunne stille op til byrådet skal en ny borgerliste kunne præsentere mindst 50 stillere, og de var betydeligt nemmere at finde end forventet, lyder det.

»Jeg tror, at vi var to, der hver især brugte godt og vel en halv dag på det, og så havde vi 66 godkendte stillere fra blandt andet Tranbjerg, Lystrup Hjortshøj, Harlev og Aarhus V. Det viser, at mange er forargede over, at kommunen vil privatisere kommunale veje,« siger Steen Jørgensen og fortsætter:

»I andre kommuner har man gjort det på en mere gennemsigtig og ordentlig måde. Her har man sagt, at alle de eksisterende udstykninger, hvor folk har boet i mange år, forbliver offentlige veje, og man oplyser om, at nye udstykninger inden for et område er private veje. Så kender borgerne vilkårene og reglerne på forhånd, og grundene kan prisfastsættes i overensstemmelse med den byrde, som vedligeholdelsespligten er.«

Bent Hansen fra Lystrup har gennem mange år været den mest markante modstander mod nedklassificering af offentlige veje i Aarhus Kommune. I 2024 tvang han byrådet til at genoptage sagen om nedklassificeringen af de 900 kommunale veje. Flere end 1.500 aarhusianere skrev under på hans borgerforslag om at annullere beslutningen, og så blev forslaget sendt til behandling i byrådet. Det ændrede dog intet.

Seks myndigheder har over syv år afvist Bent Hansens argumenter for at få Aarhus Kommune til at annullere beslutningen om nedklassificering af kommunale veje, men i marts bevilgede Civilstyrelsen Bent Hansen fri proces til at føre sag mod Vejdirektoratet.

»Bent Hansen har gjort det ganske fremragende og været virkelig god til at bringe budskabet ud. Han har kørt hele det her show og har holdt gryden i kog. Han er også nummer to på listen, hvilket er begrundet i vore overvejelser om, hvordan vi bedst har kunnet fordele opgaverne,« siger Steen Jørgensen.

Det er Danmarksdemokraternes spidskandidat Jakob Søgaard Clausen, der har stået for at samle det borgerlige valgforbund i Aarhus.

Jakob Søgaard Clausen ønsker både, at Aarhus Kommune skal stoppe med at privatisere flere veje, og at kommunen skal rulle privatiseringen tilbage for de veje, der er blevet privatiseret siden 2017, hvor man begyndte at offentliggøre de 900 veje.

Jakob Søgaard Clausen, den nye borgerliste kommer næppe ind i byrådet. Handler det her ikke bare om at rane flest mulig stemmer ind til blå blok i Aarhus?

»Nej, det synes jeg ikke. Det handler om at sende et klart signal om, at vi står sammen om det her, og vi aner jo ikke, hvordan valget går. Håbet er, at vi kan få et flertal, så vi kan sætte en stopper for privatiseringen af kommunale veje i Aarhus Kommune.«

Bør partierne i byrådet ikke respektere de forlig, de er en del af? Ellers kan borgerne jo ikke stole på de politiske aftaler, I laver.

»Det er en gammel aftale fra 2014, og jeg har ikke været med til at vedtage den. Nu, hvor man har lavet undersøgelser, kan man se, at vejene er i dårligere stand, end man havde regnet med, og byrådet er på mange punkter blevet opmærksom på, at privatiseringen af de offentlige veje slet ikke er så nem en proces, som man havde troet, det var. Det er urealistisk, og derfor er man nødt til at stoppe op.«

The issue of downgrading around 900 public roads to private shared roads has become a major theme in the upcoming municipal elections.

Recently, the Conservatives and the Liberals in Aarhus City Council withdrew from a budget agreement on the downgrading, which means that countless Aarhus landowners will have to take over the costs of maintaining the roads they live on from the municipality.

Now a new citizens' list is entering the election campaign, and the citizens' list's name says it all about the purpose of running in the municipal elections. No to privatization of municipal roads was founded by citizens who want to ensure that "municipal roads become a shared responsibility again."

The new citizens' list has joined the civic electoral alliance in Aarhus consisting of the Liberals, Conservatives, the Danish Democrats, the Liberal Alliance and the Danish People's Party. The aim is to stand united against the privatization of the roads.

"This is about us wanting to represent ordinary Aarhusians who are affected by decisions made far from reality. We want to meet the decision-makers on their own terms, and that is in the city council. As landowners, we pay fairly high taxes, and we think it is unfair that we should have such a negative bonus on top of our heads. This could ultimately mean that some people have to leave their homes,” says the Citizens’ List’s lead candidate, Steen Jørgensen.

He lives in Brabrand and is currently a lecturer in public law at Aarhus University.

A Citizens’ List is characterized by the fact that its candidates do not represent one of the traditional nationwide parties and do not have an ideological affiliation at the national level. In order to run for the city council, a new Citizens’ List must be able to present at least 50 candidates, and they were considerably easier to find than expected, it is said.

"I think there were two of us, each spending about half a day on it, and we had 66 approved bidders from, among others, Tranbjerg, Lystrup Hjortshøj, Harlev and Aarhus V. This shows that many are outraged that the municipality wants to privatize municipal roads," says Steen Jørgensen and continues:

"In other municipalities, it has been done in a more transparent and proper way. Here, it has been said that all the existing subdivisions, where people have lived for many years, will remain public roads, and it is stated that new subdivisions within an area are private roads. This way, citizens know the terms and conditions in advance, and the plots can be priced in accordance with the burden of the maintenance obligation."

Bent Hansen from Lystrup has for many years been the most prominent opponent of the downgrading of public roads in Aarhus Municipality. In 2024, he forced the city council to resume the case of the downgrading of the 900 municipal roads. More than 1,500 Aarhus residents signed his citizens' proposal to cancel the decision, and the proposal was then sent to the city council for consideration. However, this did not change anything.

For over seven years, six authorities have rejected Bent Hansen's arguments to get Aarhus Municipality to cancel the decision to downgrade municipal roads, but in March the Civil Service Board granted Bent Hansen free process to file a lawsuit against the Danish Road Directorate.

"Bent Hansen has done quite excellently and has been really good at getting the message out. He has run this whole show and has kept the pot boiling. He is also number two on the list, which is based on our considerations about how we could best distribute the tasks," says Steen Jørgensen.

The Danish Democrats' lead candidate, Jakob Søgaard Clausen, has been responsible for bringing together the civic electoral alliance in Aarhus.

Jakob Søgaard Clausen wants both that Aarhus Municipality should stop privatizing more roads, and that the municipality should roll back the privatization of roads that have been privatized since 2017, when the 900 roads began to be published.

Jakob Søgaard Clausen, the new citizens' list is unlikely to make it to the city council. Isn't this just about stealing as many votes as possible for the blue bloc in Aarhus?

"No, I don't think so. It's about sending a clear signal that we stand together on this, and we have no idea how the election will go. The hope is that we can get a majority so that we can put an end to the privatization of municipal roads in Aarhus Municipality."

Shouldn't the parties in the city council respect the settlements they are a part of? Otherwise, the citizens cannot trust the political agreements you make.

"It's an old agreement from 2014, and I was not involved in adopting it. "Now that studies have been done, we can see that the roads are in worse condition than we had expected, and the city council has become aware on many points that the privatization of public roads is not as easy a process as we had thought it would be. It is unrealistic, and therefore we have to stop."

Debatten om privatisering af kommunale veje i Aarhus er præget af både misforståelser og politisk spin. Når man læser Din Avis’ artikel “Ny stemme ind i kamp mod privatisering af veje”, fremgår det, at kommunen står klar til at vælte enorme udgifter over på 30.000 aarhusianere. Men sandheden er, at problemet ikke er privatisering i sig selv – det er måden, kommunen griber det an på.

Kommunen kalder det “nedklassificering af veje” – et teknisk og vildledende begreb, som i virkeligheden dækker over, at man vil fralægge sig ansvaret for vedligeholdelsen af veje, der i dag er kommunale. Det er en besparelse forklædt med forvaltningssprog.

Det er både urimeligt og lovstridigt, hvis Aarhus Kommune alene begrunder en nedklassificering i økonomi. For i vejloven står det klart, at beslutninger om klassificering skal træffes på baggrund af en samlet trafikal vurdering – ikke ud fra sparehensyn. Når kommunen alligevel lægger op til at “nedklassificere” veje udelukkende for at skære i budgettet, er det et klart brud på både lovens ånd og borgernes tillid.

Borgertinget siger det tydeligt: Ingen borger skal betale dobbelt for den samme vej.

Hvis kommunen vil slippe for udgiften, skal de berørte grundejere have nedsat deres grundskyld svarende til kommunens tidligere udgifter. Det er sund fornuft og simpel retfærdighed.

Her er, hvordan det kan gøres: En vej med 10 ejendomme koster kommunen 60.000 kr. årligt i drift – altså 6.000 kr. pr. ejendom. Sænkes grundskyldspromillen fra 26 til 23 ‰, sparer borgerne de samme 6.000 kr., som de fremover betaler til privat vedligehold. Så enkelt er det, hvis man vil handle ordentligt.

Men der er flere principper, som kommunen må indse: Kommunen skal aflevere vejene i fuldt funktionsdygtig stand, før ansvaret overgår til borgerne. Det er fuldstændig uacceptabelt, hvis borgerne skal overtage huller, revner og kommunalt efterslæb. Privatisering skal ske fra nulpunkt – ikke fra minus.

Der findes dog veje, hvor privatisering giver mening – f.eks. lukkede boligveje og stikveje, hvor kun beboerne selv kører. Her kan det være rimeligt, at grundejerne overtager driften, mod et tilsvarende nedslag i grundskylden. Det er samtidig mere fair over for de borgere, der bor på gennemgående veje, som fortsat vedligeholdes og sneryddes af kommunen.

Men det skal være frivilligt – ikke et krav fra byrådet. Privatisering skal være et tilbud til grundejerforeningerne, aldrig tvang. Borgerne skal have indsigt i, hvad kommunen selv bruger på vedligehold, og kunne indhente tilbud fra private leverandører, før de beslutter sig. Først da kan man tale om retfærdighed, gennemsigtighed og reelt valg.

Og så er der de samme byrådspolitikere, der for få måneder siden stemte for privatisering af kommunale veje, står nu pludselig frem og siger, at de er “blevet klogere”. Det er politik på mest populistiske vis – først stemmer man for, og når vælgerne bliver vrede, skynder man sig at mene det modsatte kort tid før kommunalvalget. Hvis dét er den form for rygmarvsregering, der skal styre Aarhus, så burde vi have kommunalvalg hver dag, så borgerne konstant kan minde deres repræsentanter om, hvem de egentlig er valgt til at repræsentere.

Borgertinget kræver, at Aarhus Kommune stopper med at misbruge begrebet “nedklassificering” som et dække for besparelser og begynder at overholde lovens krav om trafikal vurdering, faglighed og åbenhed.

Det her handler ikke kun om asfalt. Det handler om ærlighed, tillid og respekt for borgerne – og det er på tide, at byrådet lever op til det ansvar.
eng_text:
The debate about the privatization of municipal roads in Aarhus is characterized by both misunderstandings and political spin. When you read Din Avis’ article “A new voice in the fight against the privatization of roads”, it becomes clear that the municipality is ready to pass on enormous expenses to 30,000 Aarhus residents. But the truth is that the problem is not privatization itself – it is the way the municipality is approaching it.

The municipality calls it “downgrading of roads” – a technical and misleading term, which in reality covers the fact that they want to abdicate responsibility for the maintenance of roads that are currently municipal. It is a cost-saving disguised as administrative language.

It is both unreasonable and illegal for the Municipality of Aarhus to justify a downgrading solely on economic grounds. The Roads Act clearly states that decisions on classification must be made on the basis of an overall traffic assessment – not on the basis of cost-saving considerations. When the municipality nevertheless sets out to “downgrade” roads solely to cut the budget, it is a clear violation of both the spirit of the law and the citizens’ trust.

The City Council clearly states: No citizen should pay twice for the same road.

If the municipality wants to avoid the expense, the affected landowners must have their land tax reduced by the municipality’s previous expenses. This is common sense and simple justice.

Here’s how it can be done: A road with 10 properties costs the municipality DKK 60,000 annually to operate – that is DKK 6,000 per property. If the land tax percentage is lowered from 26 to 23‰, the citizens will save the same DKK 6,000 that they will pay for private maintenance in the future. It’s that simple if you want to act properly.

But there are several principles that the municipality must realize: The municipality must hand over the roads in fully functional condition before responsibility is transferred to the citizens. It is completely unacceptable if citizens have to take over potholes, cracks and municipal backlog. Privatization must be done from zero – not from minus.

However, there are roads where privatization makes sense – for example, closed residential roads and shortcut roads where only the residents drive themselves. Here it may be reasonable for the landowners to take over the operation, in exchange for a corresponding reduction in the land tax. It is also fairer to the citizens who live on through roads that continue to be maintained and snow cleared by the municipality.

But it must be voluntary – not a requirement from the city council. Privatization must be an offer to the landowners' associations, never a compulsion. Citizens must have insight into what the municipality itself spends on maintenance, and be able to obtain offers from private suppliers before they decide. Only then can we talk about fairness, transparency and real choice.

And then there are the same city council politicians who a few months ago voted for the privatization of municipal roads, now suddenly come forward and say that they have “become wiser”. This is politics at its most populist – first you vote for it, and when the voters get angry, you rush to say the opposite shortly before the municipal elections. If that is the kind of spineless government that is going to govern Aarhus, then we should have municipal elections every day, so that citizens can constantly remind their representatives of who they have actually been elected to represent.

The City Council demands that Aarhus Municipality stop abusing the concept of “downgrading” as a cover for savings and start complying with the legal requirements for traffic assessment, professionalism and transparency.

This is not just about asphalt. It is about honesty, trust and respect for the citizens – and it is time for the city council to live up to that responsibility.

Nogle politikere ser næsten rødt, når talen falder på at arbejde målrettet på at skaffe flere erhvervsvirksomheder til Syddjurs. ”Vi vil hellere tale om ældrepleje og familieliv,” har jeg hørt ytret. Men erhvervspolitik er også ældre- og familiepolitik – det hele hænger sammen.

Det er mandag morgen. Jeg afleverer ungerne på skolen, vinker farvel og sætter kursen mod min arbejdsplads på Aarhus Universitet. 50 minutters pendling hver vej. Det er 1 time og 40 minutter hver arbejdsdag, jeg i stedet kunne bruge sammen med min familie, på mit frivillige engagement i byen, på sport eller måske bare på en længere gåtur med hunden i vores smukke natur.

Vi mangler gode, stærke og gerne grønne virksomheder i Syddjurs. Og ikke bare for en kortere pendlerturs skyld – men fordi gode virksomheder skaber gode arbejdspladser, som gør det attraktivt at bosætte sig i Syddjurs, også når man skal have familieliv og arbejdsliv til at gå op i en højere enhed. Flere borgere i arbejde betyder også flere skatteindtægter i kommunekassen, som kan bruges til både ældrepleje og bedre skoler.

Når vi i Konservative vil arbejde for at styrke vores erhvervsliv, er det ikke for at vækste bare for vækstens skyld. Det er fordi, vi ved, at pengene ikke falder ned fra himlen – hverken i privatøkonomien eller i kommunekassen. Vi er nødt til at sikre en sund vækst, så vi kan skabe sunde og gode vilkår for alle i kommunen – fra vugge til grav. Det gode liv hele livet er også en afgørende hjørnesten i den konservative politik. Vi arbejder også hårdt for bedre skoler, normeringer og ældrepleje. Vi mener bare, at pengene helst skal findes ved at skabe et sundt økonomisk grundlag.

Hvis vi går sammen om at skabe de bedst mulige vilkår for både at starte virksomhed og tiltrække gode, meget gerne grønne, virksomheder til Syddjurs, skaber vi også de bedst mulige vilkår for dig og mig, som er heldige at bo og leve her. Det er derfor, Konservative gik forrest for at få etableret Erhvervsenheden, som de sidste fire år har rådgivet og hjulpet nye og etablerede virksomheder i kommunen. Og det er derfor, vi i Konservative også de næste fire år vil arbejde for at skabe gode vilkår for virksomheder i Syddjurs. Det mener vi faktisk er udvikling med omtanke – for både dig, mig og dem, vi holder af.
eng_text:
Some politicians almost see red when the topic of working purposefully to bring more businesses to Syddjurs comes up. “We would rather talk about elderly care and family life,” I have heard people say. But business policy is also elderly and family policy – it is all connected.

It is Monday morning. I drop the kids off at school, wave goodbye and head for my workplace at Aarhus University. A 50-minute commute each way. That is 1 hour and 40 minutes each working day that I could instead spend with my family, on my volunteer work in the city, doing sports or maybe just on a longer walk with the dog in our beautiful nature.

We need good, strong and preferably green businesses in Syddjurs. And not just for the sake of a shorter commute – but because good businesses create good jobs that make it attractive to settle in Syddjurs, also when you need to have family life and work life merge into a higher unity. More citizens in work also means more tax revenue in the municipal treasury, which can be used for both elderly care and better schools.

When we in the Conservative Party want to work to strengthen our business community, it is not to grow just for the sake of growth. It is because we know that money does not fall from the sky – neither in the private economy nor in the municipal treasury. We need to ensure healthy growth so that we can create healthy and good conditions for everyone in the municipality – from cradle to grave. The good life throughout life is also a crucial cornerstone of Conservative policy. We also work hard for better schools, standards and elderly care. We just believe that the money should preferably be found by creating a healthy economic foundation.

If we join forces to create the best possible conditions for both starting a business and attracting good, preferably green, companies to Syddjurs, we will also create the best possible conditions for you and me, who are lucky enough to live and work here. That is why the Conservative Party took the lead in establishing the Business Unit, which for the past four years has advised and helped new and established companies in the municipality. And that is why we at Conservative will continue to work for the next four years to create good conditions for businesses in Syddjurs. We actually believe that this is development with consideration – for you, me and those we care about.

Grundvand, kernekraft, folkeskolen, byudvikling, politikerlede, borgerinddragelse, lokale fællesskaber.

Det skortede ikke på debatemner, da der torsdag 23. oktober var valgmøde i et rustikt snedkerværksted i Todbjerg nær Vejlby i Aarhus. Snedkerværkstedet er en del af det lokale samlingssted Stengården, og fire politikere havde i silende regn fundet vej til Todbjerg, der med sine 110 husstande ikke kan kaldes en metropol.

De fire politikere var byrådskandidat Matilde Dueholm (S), byrådskandidat Heidi Printzen (K) samt byrådsmedlemmer Jakob Søgaard Clausen (DD) og Gert Bjerregaard (V). Sidstnævnte var på hjemmebane, da han er opvokset i Todbjerg, og det kunne mærkes.

Valgmødet var primært for borgere i landsbyerne Mejlby, Hårup og Todbjerg, men borgere fra Aarhus Nord i almindelighed var også velkomne. Bent Hansen fra Lystrup var taget til mødet i Todbjerg med en agenda, et angreb på Socialdemokratiet.

Bent Hansen har i mange år været en slags enmandshær med en mission om at få Aarhus Kommune til at annullere en beslutning om at nedklassificere 900 kommunale veje. En nedklassificering betyder, at beboerne på en vej overtager ansvaret for at vedligeholde vejen. De 900 kommunale veje, Bent Hansen kæmper for, deler karakteristika med de 6.000 private fællesveje i Aarhus Kommune. Ifølge kommunen er formålet med at nedklassificere de 900 veje at harmonisere vejnettet og skabe »ens vilkår for grundejerne.«

Hvis man ruller privatiseringen af de 900 veje tilbage, risikerer man ifølge Teknik og Miljø, at de 6.000 private fællesveje også skal ændre status til kommunale veje. At vedligeholde de 6.000 veje vil ifølge Teknik og Miljø koste 60-70 millioner kroner ekstra om året, og den regning er det røde flertal i Aarhus Byråd ikke specielt interesseret i at stå med.

Bent Hansen bor på Havremarken i Lystrup. Det er en af de 300 kommunale veje, Aarhus Kommune allerede har nedklassificeret til privat fællesvej. Da Bent Hansen på mødet i Todbjerg fik taletid, udlagde han først teksten for de fremmødte, og henvendte sig herefter direkte til Socialdemokratiets Matilde Dueholm.

Her er den følgende ordudveksling.

BH: »Anders Winnerskjold har sagt, at der ikke kan blive tale om, at de 300 veje, der på nuværende tidspunkt er lagt om til private veje, skal ændres tilbage til kommunale veje. Hvis de bliver lagt om, vil han også lægge de 6.000 veje om til kommunale. Jeg regner med, at det stadig er holdningen i Socialdemokratiet?«

MD: »Jeg er på dybt vand her, for jeg er socialrådgiver og ikke vejteknolog. Det, jeg forstår ved det, er, at der er et juridisk ligestillingsprincip, som ikke er noget, Socialdemokratiet har opfundet til lejligheden. Men jeg hører også, at hvis pengene kan findes, og det er der jo så nogen, der skal finde ud af, er det ikke sådan, at emnet er lukket.«

BH: »Men ved du godt, hvad ligheden er mellem de veje her?«

MD: »Fortæl mig det endelig«

BH: »Det er overskriften, privat fællesvej. Men så snart du går nedenunder, er der forskel på dem. Du må gerne hilse borgmesteren fra mig og sige, at jeg står med beviser for, at den oprindelige vedtagelse er ulovlig. Jeg står også med en udtalelse fra Vejdirektoratet, der er øverste myndighed inden for alt, der hedder veje: ”Det er ikke muligt at sammenligne et nyt boligområde, hvor vejene er født som private fællesveje, med de nedklassificerede veje. Der er således ikke tale om væsentligt lige forhold, der skal behandles ens i retlig henseende.” Så nu kan borgmesteren godt gå i realitetsforhandlinger med de borgerlige om at nedklassificere de 300 veje uden at det har nogen betydning for de 6.000 veje. Sådan. Så enkelt er det.«

Bent Hansens afsluttende kommentar blev mødt med klapsalver i snedkerværkstedet i Todbjerg.

Dette medie er i besiddelse af den afgørelse fra Vejdirektoratet, Bent Hansen refererer til, og har fredag 24. oktober kontaktet borgmester Anders Winnerskjold og telefonisk gengivet ordudvekslingen mellem Bent Hansen og Matilde Dueholm.

Det virker til, at Aarhus’ borgmester er knap så afvisende over for at annullere beslutningen om at nedklassificere de 900 kommunale veje.

»Vi anerkender de gener, det skaber at nedklassificere vejene. Min forvaltning siger, der er et juridisk ligestillingsprincip. Det er vi nødt til at tage for gode varer, men skulle det ændre sig, vil vi gerne tage en dialog om, hvordan man kan finde vej i det her. Det er ekstremt kompleks jura, men vores holdning er, at vi gerne vil se på det,« siger han.

Ifølge Anders Winnerskjold er det op til Venstre og Konservative, der for nylig trak sig fra et budgetforlig om nedklassificeringen, at komme med et forslag til, hvordan man kan løse situationen, uden at Aarhus Kommune kommer til at stå med en stor regning.

»Det er dem, der har opsagt et forlig og vil gøre noget anderledes. De byder op til dans, men vi skal lige tage stilling til, hvilken dans vi skal danse. Der har været fuldstændig stille om, hvordan man skal løse det her. Vi mangler et klart bud fra de borgerlige om, hvordan man vil gøre det.«

Anders Winnerskjold ønsker ikke at forholde sig til Bent Hansens tolkning af en tekst fra Vejdirektoratet.
eng_text:
Groundwater, nuclear power, primary school, urban development, political leadership, citizen involvement, local communities.

There was no shortage of debate topics when an election meeting was held on Thursday, October 23, in a rustic carpentry workshop in Todbjerg near Vejlby in Aarhus. The carpentry workshop is part of the local gathering place Stengården, and four politicians had found their way to Todbjerg in pouring rain, which with its 110 households cannot be called a metropolis.

The four politicians were city council candidate Matilde Dueholm (S), city council candidate Heidi Printzen (K) and city council members Jakob Søgaard Clausen (DD) and Gert Bjerregaard (V). The latter was on home turf, as he grew up in Todbjerg, and it was noticeable.

The election meeting was primarily for citizens in the villages of Mejlby, Hårup and Todbjerg, but citizens from Aarhus Nord in general were also welcome. Bent Hansen from Lystrup had come to the meeting in Todbjerg with an agenda, an attack on the Social Democrats.

For many years, Bent Hansen has been a kind of one-man army with a mission to get the Municipality of Aarhus to cancel a decision to downgrade 900 municipal roads. Downgrading means that the residents of a road take over the responsibility for maintaining the road. The 900 municipal roads that Bent Hansen is fighting for share characteristics with the 6,000 private public roads in the Municipality of Aarhus. According to the municipality, the purpose of downgrading the 900 roads is to harmonize the road network and create “equal conditions for landowners.”

If the privatization of the 900 roads is rolled back, according to Teknik og Miljø, there is a risk that the 6,000 private public roads will also have to change their status to municipal roads. According to Teknik og Miljø, maintaining the 6,000 roads will cost an extra 60-70 million kroner per year, and the red majority in Aarhus City Council is not particularly interested in footing that bill.

Bent Hansen lives on Havremarken in Lystrup. It is one of the 300 municipal roads that Aarhus Municipality has already downgraded to private public roads. When Bent Hansen was given the floor at the meeting in Todbjerg, he first explained the text to those present, and then addressed the Social Democrats' Matilde Dueholm directly.

Here is the following exchange of words.

BH: »Anders Winnerskjold has said that there can be no question of the 300 roads that are currently converted to private roads being changed back to municipal roads. If they are converted, he will also convert the 6,000 roads to municipal roads. I assume that's still the position of the Social Democrats?»

MD: »I'm in deep water here, because I'm a social worker and not a road engineer. What I understand by that is that there is a legal principle of equality, which is not something that the Social Democrats have invented for the occasion. But I also hear that if the money can be found, and there is someone who has to find out, it's not like the issue is closed.«

BH: »But do you know what the similarity is between these roads?«

MD: »Tell me about it.«

BH: »That's the headline, private public road. But as soon as you go downstairs, there's a difference between them. Please give my regards to the mayor and tell him that I have evidence that the original adoption is illegal. I also have a statement from the Danish Road Directorate, which is the supreme authority for all things road: “It is not possible to compare a new residential area where the roads were born as private public roads with the downgraded roads. Thus, there is no question of substantially equal conditions that must be treated equally in legal terms.” So now the mayor can enter into substantive negotiations with the civic authorities to downgrade the 300 roads without it having any effect on the 6,000 roads. Like that. It is that simple.“

Bent Hansen’s closing comment was met with applause in the carpentry workshop in Todbjerg.

This media outlet is in possession of the decision from the Danish Road Directorate that Bent Hansen refers to, and on Friday, October 24, contacted Mayor Anders Winnerskjold and reproduced the exchange of words between Bent Hansen and Matilde Dueholm by telephone.

It seems that the mayor of Aarhus is not so reluctant to cancel the decision to downgrade the 900 municipal roads.

“We recognize the inconvenience caused by downgrading the roads. My administration says that there is a legal principle of equality. We have to take that for granted, but if that changes, we would like to have a dialogue about how to find a way around this. It is extremely complex law, but our position is that we would like to look at it,” he says.

According to Anders Winnerskjold, it is up to the Liberal Party and the Conservative Party, who recently withdrew from a budget agreement on the downgrading, to come up with a proposal for how to resolve the situation without the Municipality of Aarhus being left with a large bill.

“They are the ones who have terminated the agreement and want to do something different. They are offering to dance, but we have to decide which dance to dance. There has been complete silence about how to resolve this. We need a clear proposal from the civil society on how to do it. "

Anders Winnerskjold does not want to comment on Bent Hansen's interpretation of a text from the Danish Road Directorate.

Socialdemokratiet og SF ønsker en betalingsring for bilister som hovedgreb i deres Grønne mobilitetsplan. Ifølge planen skal den levere halvdelen af Aarhus’ CO₂-reduktion, men uden at forklare, hvordan det konkret skal ske, og uden finansiering.

Regnestykket betyder i praksis, at aarhusianere med fossil bil skal køre omkring 7.900 kilometer mindre om året, det svar har vi fået fra forvaltningen. Det svarer til næsten halvdelen af den årlige privatkørsel for mange familier. Vi har spurgt igen og igen, hvordan det skal lade sig gøre i virkeligheden. Vi venter stadig på svar.

Imens ved vi én ting: en betalingsring for bilister vil ramme hverdagens mennesker hårdest. Sygeplejersken fra Kolt, håndværkeren fra Sabro, læreren i Mårslet og familierne i Brabrand og Harlev. Ikke alle kan tage cyklen i myldretiden. Ikke alle kan tage letbanen. Ikke alle bor i midtbyen.

Det er ikke social retfærdighed. Det er en hverdagsstraf – og en løsning uden plan.

Aarhus fortjener en grøn omstilling, som samler byen og giver reelle mobilitetsmuligheder. Derfor har Venstre som det eneste parti fremlagt en konkret alternativ plan, der giver: bedre og billigere kollektiv transport, hurtige elbusser (BRT) som i Aalborg, intelligente lyskryds og investeringer i vejnettet. Det mener vi giver fremkommelighed for alle – ikke flere afgifter på almindelige menneskers liv.

Aarhus skal være en by, hvor man kan komme rundt, arbejde og leve uanset postnummer og indkomst. En betalingsring for bilister skaber ulighed og gør hverdagen dyrere.

Aarhus skal være en åben by – nej tak til en betalingsmur.
eng_text:
The Social Democrats and the Socialist Party want a toll ring for drivers as the main measure in their Green Mobility Plan. According to the plan, it should deliver half of Aarhus' CO₂ reduction, but without explaining how this will be done specifically, and without financing.

In practice, the calculation means that Aarhusians with fossil-fuel cars will have to drive around 7,900 kilometers less per year, the answer we have received from the administration. This corresponds to almost half of the annual private driving for many families. We have asked again and again how this will be done in reality. We are still waiting for an answer.

In the meantime, we know one thing: a toll ring for drivers will hit everyday people the hardest. The nurse from Kolt, the craftsman from Sabro, the teacher in Mårslet and the families in Brabrand and Harlev. Not everyone can take the bike during rush hour. Not everyone can take the light rail. Not everyone lives in the city center.

This is not social justice. It is an everyday punishment – and a solution without a plan.

Aarhus deserves a green transition that unites the city and provides real mobility opportunities. That is why Venstre is the only party to have presented a concrete alternative plan that provides: better and cheaper public transport, fast electric buses (BRT) like in Aalborg, intelligent traffic lights and investments in the road network. We believe this provides accessibility for everyone – not more taxes on the lives of ordinary people.

Aarhus must be a city where you can get around, work and live regardless of zip code and income. A toll ring for drivers creates inequality and makes everyday life more expensive.

Aarhus must be an open city – no thanks to a toll wall.

Folkeskolen skal have opbakning fra alle i Aarhus. Sådan lyder det fra Thomas Medom (SF), der i otte år har været rådmand for Børn- og Ungeudvalget i Aarhus Kommune.

- Jeg tror på, at det giver stor forståelse for alle mulige forskellige typer mennesker, hvis vi har mange, der går i den lokale folkeskole og mødes på kryds og tværs.

Men det er ikke alle steder, at den ambition har mundet ud i lige stor tilslutning til den lokale folkeskole.

I landets største kommuner København, Aarhus, Odense og Aalborg har en række folkeskoler så svært ved at tiltrække elever, at under halvdelen af eleverne fra skoledistriktet faktisk går på deres lokale folkeskole.

Forældrene vælger i stedet, at deres børn skal gå på en fri- eller privatskole eller på en anden folkeskole, der ligger i et andet skoledistrikt.

Det fremgår af svar fra en række kommuner til DR Nyheder.

I Aarhus Kommune er det på hver fjerde folkeskole, at under halvdelen af eleverne, der går på skolen, egentlig hører til den. Thomas Medom mener, at DR’s tal på ’de fleste skoler’ ikke er udtryk for noget problematisk.

- Men der er også nogle af de skoler, der bliver fravalgt, hvor der er integrationsudfordringer, og hvor næsten 100 procent af eleverne er tosprogede.

- Der synes jeg, det bliver en udfordring, at vi ikke har blandede skoler, og der vil jeg kæmpe for, at de skoler i højere grad får fat i de lokale forældre.

Også Thomas Medoms kollega i Børne- og Ungeudvalget i Aarhus Kommune, Mathilde Hjort Bressum (V) mener, at integrationen bærer en del af ansvaret for, at forældre i højere grad end tidligere fravælger den kommunale folkeskole.

- Det er jo en konstatering af, at der er nogle forældre, som ikke synes, at deres børn skal gå i en folkeskole, hvor der er en rigtig høj andel af tosprogede børn. Så det er også en konstatering af de integrationsudfordringer, vi har mange steder i vores by.

Begge politikere peger også på, at boligpolitikken i Aarhus Kommune skal ændres, hvis flere folkeskoler skal blive mere attraktive og mangfoldige.

- Når Aarhus Kommune er en af de kommuner, hvor vi er mest opdelte i vores skolevæsen, er det, fordi vi er Danmarks mest opdelte by, i forhold til hvordan vi bor. Så vores hovedudfordring er vores boligmarked, siger Thomas Medom.

Og netop derfor skal der fokuseres på, hvor aarhusianerne bor, mener Mathilde Hjort Bressum.

- Det er et langt sejt træk at ændre en boligsammensætning, men det er det, jeg mener, der skal til for at løse den her opgave bedst muligt og mest bæredygtigt - også på lang sigt. 

Tendensen med at forældre fravælger den lokale folkeskole bliver kaldt ’et vink med en vognstang’ af Dansk Folkepartis spidskandidat til Aarhus byråd, Thomas Kastrup Christensen.

Han mener, at det i høj grad drejer sig om, at der er for meget uro i klasserne.

- Vi skal have en meget, meget klar strategi for, at ro og disciplin skal komme først. Der er ingen elever, der kan lære noget, så længe der foregår uro i klassen, siger Thomas Kastrup Christensen.

The primary school must have the support of everyone in Aarhus. This is according to Thomas Medom (SF), who has been a councillor for the Children and Youth Committee in Aarhus Municipality for eight years.

- I believe that it gives great understanding for all sorts of different types of people if we have many people who go to the local primary school and meet in different ways.

But not everywhere has that ambition resulted in the same level of support for the local primary school.

In the country's largest municipalities of Copenhagen, Aarhus, Odense and Aalborg, a number of primary schools have such difficulty attracting students that less than half of the students from the school district actually go to their local primary school.

Parents instead choose for their children to go to a free or private school or to another primary school located in a different school district.

This is evident from responses from a number of municipalities to DR Nyheder.

In Aarhus Municipality, in every fourth primary school, less than half of the students who go to the school actually belong to it. Thomas Medom believes that DR's figures on 'most schools' do not indicate anything problematic.

- But there are also some of the schools that are being opted out, where there are integration challenges, and where almost 100 percent of the students are bilingual.

- I think it will be a challenge there that we do not have mixed schools, and I will fight for those schools to reach out to local parents to a greater extent.

Thomas Medom's colleague on the Children and Youth Committee in Aarhus Municipality, Mathilde Hjort Bressum (V) also believes that integration bears part of the responsibility for parents opting out of the municipal primary school to a greater extent than before.

- It is a finding that there are some parents who do not think that their children should go to a primary school where there is a very high proportion of bilingual children. So it is also a finding of the integration challenges that we have in many places in our city.

Both politicians also point out that the housing policy in Aarhus Municipality must be changed if more primary schools are to become more attractive and diverse.

- When Aarhus Municipality is one of the municipalities where we are most divided in our school system, it is because we are Denmark's most divided city, in relation to how we live. So our main challenge is our housing market, says Thomas Medom.

And that is precisely why we must focus on where Aarhusians live, says Mathilde Hjort Bressum.

- It is a long haul to change a housing composition, but that is what I believe is needed to solve this task in the best possible and most sustainable way - also in the long term. 

The trend of parents opting out of the local primary school is called 'a sign with a wagon pole' by the Danish People's Party's lead candidate for Aarhus city council, Thomas Kastrup Christensen.

He believes that it is largely about there being too much unrest in the classes.

- We need to have a very, very clear strategy that calm and discipline come first. No student can learn anything as long as there is unrest in the classroom, says Thomas Kastrup Christensen.

Over 70 kommuner har det. Samtlige østjyske kommuner. Sågar landets mindste, Læsø.

I Aarhus er der også byråds-tv, hvor borgerne live eller ’on demand’ kan følge med i debatterne i byrådssalen, men det kan snart være fortid med video fra byrådsmøderne i landets næststørste kommune.

Et flertal er nemlig indstillet på at gå tilbage til lydoptagelse af møderne og derved spare udgifterne.

»Det er jo penge, vi ikke kan bruge til andet. Vi har intet imod projektet, men vi synes bare ikke, at det er noget, borgerne skal betale for. Det er ikke en kommunal kerneopgave,« mener de konservatives gruppeformand Peter Sporleder.

Ordningen med byråds-tv, der har kørt som et forsøg siden 2023 og løber frem til 2026, koster kommunen 200.000 kroner om året. Småpenge i et milliardbudget, men mange bække små, lyder det fra Sporleder.

»Mange små beløb løber op og bliver store beløb. Og der er jo ikke mange, der ser det.«

Det er mildt sagt. En opgørelse, som forvaltningen har lavet, viser, at hvert byrådsmøde i gennemsnit har blot 427 unikke seere. Altså ser cirka en promille af den aarhusianske befolkning med, når politikerne debatterer kommunale anliggender hver anden onsdag.

Det meget lave seertal er også årsagen til, at Socialdemokratiet er klar til at droppe tv-sendingen.

»Det er ikke en stor prioritering for Socialdemokratiet at have video på. Den gamle ordning, hvor man kunne lytte til møderne, var helt fin. Hvis så få ser med, så synes jeg godt, at vi kan diskutere, om det kan betale sig,« forklarer politisk ordfører Jesper Kjeldsen.

Næsten alle andre kommuner har tv - selv landets mindste kommune. Er det ikke en falliterklæring, hvis landets næststørste ikke har?

»Jeg ved ikke, hvordan finansieringen og prisen er hos de andre byråd, men nej, det mener jeg ikke, når prisen pr. seer er så dyr,« siger Jesper Kjeldsen.

»Vi kan også vende den om og spørge, om vi ikke netop så skal gå foran som stor kommuner og trække en streg i sandet,« lyder det fra Sporleder.

»Vi har forsøgt i håbet om, at flere ville følge debatterne, men interessen har ikke været der. Var tallene anderledes, havde vi nok set anderledes på det.«

Ideen om at sløjfe byråds-tv møder dog modstand fra flere af byrådets partier.

Venstre, Liberal Alliance, Danmarksdemokraterne og Moderaterne har således slået sig sammen og lavet et budgetforslag for at bevare det.

»Jeg synes, det vil være et meget mærkeligt signal at sende, hvis landets næststørste kommune ikke kan finde midler til at have byråds-tv. Som stor kommune er det bestemt noget, som hører sig til i 2025,« fastslår Jakob Søgaard Clausen (DD), der selv bruger ordningen meget.

Han klipper blandt andet videoer ned fra byrådsmøderne, som han bruger på de sociale medier. Det mest sete klip har fået 127.000 visninger.

»Derfor er forvaltningens tal også misvisende. Lokalmedierne bruger også klip i udvalgte sager, så jeg vil mene, at byråds-tv har en meget større udbredelse, end man lige tror,« pointerer han.

Men det argument køber Jesper Kjeldsen ikke.

»Jeg kan godt forstå, hvis de synes, at det er træls, at de ikke kan bruge det til det mere. Men Jakob har selv været meget kritisk overfor, hvordan rådmænd og borgmesteren får understøttelse af forvaltningen til deres sociale medier, så man kan jo spørge, om skatteborgernes penge skal bruges på at finansiere Jakob Søgaard Clausens videoer på Facebook? Det mener jeg nok ikke.«

Det handler dog også om at have et åbent lokaldemokrati, som er tilgængeligt for de borgere, der ikke lige tropper op på rådhuset for at følge slagets gang, understreger danmarksdemokraten.

»Jeg tror bestemt, at det er med til at gøre lokalpolitik mere nært, at man kan få sat ansigt på politikerne og se, hvad de arbejder for.«

De fire partier, der vil bevare ordningen, foreslår, at de 200.000 kroner findes ved at skære i en studentermedhælperordning, så de store partier ikke får mere hjælp end de andre. Og så vil de droppe gratis medier, aviser og it for ca. 130.000 om året til borgmesteren og rådmændene.

»Med et årligt vederlag på over en million kroner kan de selv afholde disse udgifter eller få det dækket via deres forvaltning,« skriver forslagsstillerne.

»Jeg har set andre projekter i Aarhus Kommune, der koster væsentligt mere end det her, hvor man sagtens kan finde den slags penge. Men vi vil gerne være ansvarlige, og hvis pengene skal gå fra budgettet til byrådets arbejdsvilkår, så er det oplagt at kigge på de store partier, som allerede har en uforholdsmæssig stor understøttelse af forvaltningen,« siger Jakob Søgaard Clausen.

Gør I det ikke sværere at få igennem, når I målrettet går efter de store partier med jeres forslag?

»Det ved jeg ikke. Så må de jo forsvare, hvorfor de synes, at det er vigtigere at bruge penge på aviser til borgmesteren og rådmændene. Det er i hvert fald et konkret finansieringsforslag.«

Vil man følge byrådsdebatterne, sker det på aarhus.kommune-tv.dk, og det er ikke altid så kedeligt, som nogen gør det til.
eng_text:
Over 70 municipalities have it. All municipalities in East Jutland. Even the country's smallest, Læsø.

In Aarhus, there is also city council TV, where citizens can follow the debates in the city council chamber live or 'on demand', but that may soon be a thing of the past with video from city council meetings in the country's second-largest municipality.

A majority is set on going back to audio recording the meetings and thereby saving costs.

"It's money we can't use for anything else. We have nothing against the project, but we just don't think it's something the citizens should pay for. It's not a core municipal task," says Peter Sporleder, the Conservatives' group chairman.

The city council TV scheme, which has been running as a trial since 2023 and will run until 2026, costs the municipality 200,000 kroner per year. Small money in a billion-dollar budget, but many streams are small, says Sporleder.

"Many small amounts add up to large amounts. And not many people watch it."

That's putting it mildly. A calculation made by the administration shows that each city council meeting has an average of just 427 unique viewers. That means that about one per thousand of the Aarhus population watches when politicians debate municipal affairs every other Wednesday.

The very low viewership is also the reason why the Social Democrats are ready to drop the TV broadcast.

"It's not a big priority for the Social Democrats to have video on. The old system, where you could listen to the meetings, was perfectly fine. If so few watch, then I think we can discuss whether it's worth it," explains political spokesman Jesper Kjeldsen.

Almost all other municipalities have TV - even the country's smallest municipality. Isn't it a declaration of bankruptcy if the country's second largest doesn't have one?

»I don't know how the financing and the price are with the other city councils, but no, I don't think so, when the price per viewer is so expensive,« says Jesper Kjeldsen.

»We can also turn it around and ask whether we shouldn't take the lead as a large municipality and draw a line in the sand,« says Sporleder.

»We have tried in the hope that more people would follow the debates, but the interest has not been there. If the numbers were different, we would probably have looked at it differently.«

The idea of scrapping city council TV, however, is meeting resistance from several of the city council's parties.

The Liberal Party, Liberal Alliance, the Danish Democrats and the Moderates have thus joined forces and made a budget proposal to preserve it.

»I think it would be a very strange signal to send if the country's second largest municipality cannot find the funds to have city council TV. As a large municipality, it is definitely something that belongs in 2025,” states Jakob Søgaard Clausen (DD), who himself uses the scheme a lot.

Among other things, he cuts videos from city council meetings, which he uses on social media. The most viewed clip has received 127,000 views.

“That is why the administration’s figures are also misleading. The local media also use clips in selected cases, so I would say that city council TV has a much wider distribution than one might think,” he points out.

But Jesper Kjeldsen does not buy that argument.

“I can understand if they think it is a pain that they cannot use it for that anymore. But Jakob himself has been very critical of how councillors and the mayor receive support from the administration for their social media, so one could ask, should taxpayers’ money be used to finance Jakob Søgaard Clausen’s videos on Facebook? I don't think so. 

However, it is also about having an open local democracy that is accessible to those citizens who don't just turn up at the town hall to follow the battle, emphasizes the Danish Democrat. 

"I definitely think that it helps to make local politics more accessible, that you can put a face to the politicians and see what they are working for." 

The four parties that want to maintain the scheme propose that the 200,000 kroner be found by cutting a student assistant scheme, so that the big parties don't get more help than the others. And then they want to drop free media, newspapers and IT for approx. 130,000 a year for the mayor and councillors. 

"With an annual remuneration of over a million kroner, they can cover these expenses themselves or have it covered through their administration," write the proposers. 

"I have seen other projects in Aarhus Municipality that cost significantly more than this, where you can easily find that kind of money. But we want to be responsible, and if the money is going to go from the budget to the city council's working conditions, it is obvious to look at the big parties, which already have a disproportionate amount of support for the administration," says Jakob Søgaard Clausen.

Don't you make it harder to get through when you specifically go after the big parties with your proposals?

"I don't know. Then they have to defend why they think it is more important to spend money on newspapers to the mayor and councilors. That is at least a concrete financing proposal."

If you want to follow the city council debates, it is on aarhus.kommune-tv.dk, and it is not always as boring as some make it out to be.
