eng_text:
The port expansion caused a worse uproar and protest storm, but what do ordinary Aarhusians actually think about the politicians' ideas?

Do they want more light rail or not? Throw more tax money into the stadium? Pay to drive in the city?

We now get answers to this and much more in a survey that Epinion has conducted for the Constructive Institute and a number of media and foundations.

1,327 Aarhusians were asked 11 specific questions about local issues that have played a role in the political debate in the municipality, and some rather interesting insights have emerged.

Among other things, it turns out that there is not much support for the city council's handling of the stadium scandal.

Only 27 percent agree or strongly agree with the decision to throw more tax money into the new stadium. Furthermore, 72 percent of those surveyed believe that savings should be made on the project if it turns out that the costs will increase further.

And as for the port expansion, 44 percent actually think it was a good idea.

Aarhusians have also been asked about home care, the tobacco ban, high-rise construction, Vesterbro Torv, windmills in the port and more.

Der er noget grundlæggende galt med den måde, vi behandler folkeskolen på. Det, der skulle være børnenes trygge og faglige fundament, er blevet en kampplads for politiske eksperimenter og økonomiske nedskæringer. Resultatet? Uro i klasserne, lærere på randen af udbrændthed – og børn, der ikke får den støtte, de har brug for.

Siden inklusionsloven i 2012 har tusindvis af børn med særlige behov mistet deres specialtilbud og er blevet placeret i almene klasser. Ikke fordi det gav mening pædagogisk – men fordi det skulle spare penge. Lærerne blev efterladt med opgaven, uden ekstra hænder og uden specialpædagogisk backup. Det har skabt mistrivsel og fagligt efterslæb. For både de børn, der skulle inkluderes, og dem, der allerede var der.

Samtidig har vi skåret i lærernes forberedelsestid, fjernet deres fleksibilitet og lagt dem i spændetrøje med rigide arbejdstidsaftaler. De får mindre tid til at planlægge undervisning, mindre tid til at samarbejde med kolleger og mindre tid til at se det enkelte barn. Det er ikke mærkeligt, at mange dygtige lærere forlader faget – og at vi har svært ved at tiltrække nye.

Kommunerne har lukket specialklasser i stor stil. Men reelle alternativer er udeblevet. De såkaldte mellemformer, hvor børn med særlige behov kan få støtte uden at blive segregeret, eksisterer mest som skåltaler. I praksis står læreren alene med opgaven – og børnene betaler prisen.

Det kan ikke være rigtigt, at det altid er børnene, der skal tilpasse sig skolen og de kasser, vi har indrettet. Skolen skal også kunne tilpasse sig børnene. Vi må skabe en folkeskole, hvor der er plads til forskellighed, og hvor rammerne kan bøjes, så alle børn kan finde deres plads og potentiale.

Vi har brug for et opgør – ikke endnu en reform

Folkeskolen er ikke bare presset. Den er i systemisk krise. Vi har brug for et opgør med tomme inklusionsmål, med nedskæringer forklædt som pædagogik og med en politisk kultur, der ser folkeskolen som en budgetpost i stedet for en samfundsbærende institution.

Som forælder og kandidat til Aarhus Byråd vil jeg kæmpe for:

Folkeskolen skal ikke være et eksperiment. Den skal være et løfte til vores børn. Det løfte har vi svigtet. Det er på tide, vi holder det igen – for alle børn, også dem, der har brug for lidt mere.

Et Aarhus for aarhusianere – mindre system, mere borger.
eng_text:
There is something fundamentally wrong with the way we treat primary school. What was supposed to be the children's safe and professional foundation has become a battleground for political experiments and financial cuts. The result? Unrest in the classrooms, teachers on the verge of burnout – and children who do not receive the support they need.

Since the Inclusion Act in 2012, thousands of children with special needs have lost their special education and have been placed in mainstream classes. Not because it made sense pedagogically – but because it was supposed to save money. Teachers were left with the task, without extra hands and without special educational backup. This has created dissatisfaction and academic backlog. For both the children who were to be included and those who were already there.

At the same time, we have cut teachers' preparation time, removed their flexibility and put them in a straitjacket with rigid working hours agreements. They have less time to plan teaching, less time to collaborate with colleagues and less time to see the individual child. It is no wonder that many talented teachers are leaving the profession – and that we are having difficulty attracting new ones.

Municipalities have closed special classes in a big way. But real alternatives have failed to materialize. The so-called intermediate forms, where children with special needs can receive support without being segregated, exist mostly as a toast. In practice, the teacher is left alone with the task – and the children pay the price.

It cannot be right that it is always the children who have to adapt to the school and the boxes we have set up. The school must also be able to adapt to the children. We must create a primary school where there is room for diversity, and where the framework can be bent so that all children can find their place and potential.

We need a showdown – not another reform

The primary school is not just under pressure. It is in systemic crisis. We need to confront empty inclusion goals, cuts disguised as pedagogy and a political culture that sees primary school as a budget item instead of a society-supporting institution.

As a parent and candidate for Aarhus City Council, I will fight for:

Primary school should not be an experiment. It should be a promise to our children. We have failed in that promise. It is time we keep it again – for all children, including those who need a little more.

An Aarhus for Aarhusians – less system, more citizens.

»Vigtig kampagne og fed t-shirt, som jeg glæder mig til at bære og støtte op om.«

Sådan skrev byrådspolitiker Christian Budde (V) forleden på sin facebookside.

Han har støttet aarhusianske erhvervsdrivende. For nylig gik ejerne af Slagter-Riget og P. Clausens Fiskehandel, Mark Purkær og Jakob Clausen, sammen om at lave en kampagne via en t-shirt med teksten: »Vi vil have Aarhus tilbage.«

Hvordan hjælper det erhvervslivet, at du køber denne t-shirt?

»Vi støtter op om kampagnen, og det håber jeg, at alle partier i Aarhus Byråd vil gøre. Vi er her jo for borgernes og handelslivets skyld. Der er ikke nogen, som ønsker en død midtby. Tværtimod oplever jeg, at mine kollegaer taler byen op,« siger Christian Budde (V).

Til avisen fortalte de to erhvervsdrivende, at tanken bag trøjen kom i kølvandet på flere episoder, hvor de hver især har oplevet blandt andet at miste parkeringspladser. Den seneste episode fandt sted foran Slagter-Riget på M. P. Bruuns Gade, hvor et anlægsprojekt kostede Mark Purkær halvanden parkeringsplads.

»Vi er frustrerede over, at det nye Aarhus, der bliver skabt, spænder ben for os erhvervsdrivende. Jeg valgte at tage fat i Jakob Clausen, der også er en god stemme i erhvervslivet,« sagde Mark Purkær den anden dag til avisen.

Sammen med Jakob Clausen har han skabt endnu et opråb til politikerne.

Da Slagter-Riget i august oplevede udfordringer som følge af et anlægsprojekt, troppede Christian Budde (V) op til en snak med Mark Purkær. Nu understreger han over for avisen, at det er vigtigt, at politikerne sørger for handlinger fremfor blot at have kaffedialoger.

Var det ikke netop bare dialog, da du mødte op foran Slagter-Riget?

»Vi har været ude og tale med flere forskellige erhvervsdrivende om deres udfordringer. Vi vil undersøge helt konkret, hvordan de erhvervsdrivende bliver udfordret, før vi kan gå videre med løsninger,« siger han.

Siden har han talt med erhvervsdrivende om, hvordan de er påvirket af midtbyens forandringer.

»Der er særligt to dagsordener, som går de erhvervsdrivende på. For det første er der alt omkring fremkommelighed og nedlukning af veje, som gør det sværere og sværere at have en butik i midtbyen. For det andet kan der være ting i forhold til f.eks. sommergågader. Det er besluttet, at de skal vare indtil uge 43, hvilket de erhvervsdrivende er uforstående over for, fordi vejret er blevet dårligere,« siger byrådspolitikeren.

En undersøgelse fra Dansk Industri om lokal erhvervsvenlighed har vist, at Aarhus er gået fra at ligge på en 65. plads til at ligge på en 72. plads. Det betyder, at ud af landets 98 kommuner ligger Aarhus langt nede på listen.

Det bekymrer Christian Budde (V), der håber på, at løsninger snarest kommer på den politiske dagsorden.

»Vi er i gang med en byrådsindstilling, hvor vi tager alt det her med. Det tror jeg er det bedste, vi kan gøre lige nu,« siger han.

Kan du give eksempler på, hvordan du vil forsøge at hjælpe erhvervsdrivende?

»Vi er nødt til at kigge på f.eks. parkering. Jeg har hørt konkrete eksempler på, at man kan have en jobsamtale med en ny medarbejder. Hvis ikke man kan tilbyde medarbejderen et sted at parkere sin bil i midtbyen, så siger mange nej tak og får job et andet sted. Det betyder, at de kan have svært ved at fastholde deres medarbejdere. Samtidig har de brug for parkering, hvor de kan få lastet deres varer. Her risikerer de at få bøder, fordi der ikke er parkering til dem. I sidste ende rammer det kunderne.
eng_text:
»Important campaign and cool t-shirt, which I look forward to wearing and supporting.«

This is what city council politician Christian Budde (V) wrote the other day on his Facebook page.

He has supported Aarhus business owners. Recently, the owners of Slagter-Riget and P. Clausens Fiskehandel, Mark Purkær and Jakob Clausen, joined forces to create a campaign via a t-shirt with the text: »We want Aarhus back.«

How does buying this t-shirt help the business community?

»We support the campaign, and I hope that all parties in Aarhus City Council will do so. We are here for the citizens and the business community. No one wants a dead city center. On the contrary, I experience that my colleagues are speaking up for the city,« says Christian Budde (V).

The two businessmen told the newspaper that the idea behind the shirt came in the wake of several incidents in which they have each experienced, among other things, losing parking spaces. The most recent incident took place in front of Slagter-Riget on M. P. Bruuns Gade, where a construction project cost Mark Purkær one and a half parking spaces.

"We are frustrated that the new Aarhus that is being created is straining the legs of us businessmen. I chose to take action against Jakob Clausen, who is also a good voice in the business community," Mark Purkær told the newspaper the other day.

Together with Jakob Clausen, he has created another appeal to politicians.

When Slagter-Riget experienced challenges in August as a result of a construction project, Christian Budde (V) came up for a talk with Mark Purkær. Now he emphasizes to the newspaper that it is important that politicians take action rather than just having coffee conversations.

Wasn't it just dialogue when you showed up in front of Slagter-Riget?

"We have been out and about talking to several different business owners about their challenges. We want to examine in detail how business owners are being challenged before we can move forward with solutions," he says.

He has since spoken to business owners about how they are being affected by the changes in the city centre.

"There are two agendas in particular that are on the minds of business owners. Firstly, there is everything about accessibility and the closure of roads, which makes it more and more difficult to have a shop in the city centre. Secondly, there may be things in relation to, for example, summer pedestrian streets. It has been decided that they will last until week 43, which business owners are not understanding because the weather has worsened," says the city council politician.

A survey by the Confederation of Danish Industry on local business friendliness has shown that Aarhus has gone from being in 65th place to being in 72nd place. This means that out of the country's 98 municipalities, Aarhus is far down the list.

This worries Christian Budde (V), who hopes that solutions will soon be on the political agenda.

“We are working on a city council proposal where we will include all of this. I think that is the best thing we can do right now,” he says.

Can you give examples of how you will try to help businesses?

“We need to look at, for example, parking. I have heard specific examples of how you can have a job interview with a new employee. If you cannot offer the employee a place to park their car in the city center, many will say no and get a job somewhere else. This means that they may have difficulty retaining their employees. At the same time, they need parking where they can load their goods. Here they risk getting fines because there is no parking for them. Ultimately, this affects the customers.

text:
I Vestergade i Aarhus går beboere og erhvervsdrivende rundt med ondt i maven, fordi de hver eneste dag ser farlige trafiksituationer i deres gade.

»Det er bare et spørgsmål om tid, før der sker et virkelig alvorligt uheld med den værst tænkelige udgang. Den anden dag var en fodgænger lige ved at blive kørt ned, fordi hun ikke så sig for, da hun gik ud på gaden. Hun troede, det var en gågade. Bagefter fik en parkeret varevogn en cyklist til at vælge fortovet, hvor hun ikke kunne se en barnevogn med to mennesker dreje rundt om varevognen og komme imod sig. Hun måtte bremse meget hårdt op, og hjerterne sad i halsen,« forklarer Janne Gabriel.

Avisen har flere gange bragt fotos og videoer, som dokumenterer de store udfordringer i gaden.

Erhvervsdrivende og beboere har gentagne gange forklaret, at de oplever knallerter fræse gennem gaden på fortovet, at skraldebiler torpederer cyklister og kæmpe turistbusser, der ikke kan komme ud af den smalle gade. De fylder det hele, når de bakker mange gange for at komme om hjørnerne og rammer caféernes møbler - hidtil når der ikke har siddet mennesker i dem.

Også biler, der kører mod ensretningen, gør det kaotisk.

Man kan undre sig over, om de alle har glemt færdselsreglerne? Men ifølge gadens handlende skyldes det mangel på skiltning og at den nye indretning af gaden forvirrer.

Morten Skou Nicolaisen fra Aarhus Kommune har modtaget en længere række henvendelser og siger nu, at kommunen har et internt møde næste uge om situationen i Vestergade med henblik på evt. yderligere tiltag for at hindre den uhensigtsmæssige trafikantadfærd.

Radikale Venstres Metin Aydin fra Aarhus Byråd er ikke i tvivl om, at noget må ske i Vestergade.

»Folks sikkerhed er så vigtig, at der må handles på situationen. Men vi mangler en analyse af de forskellige muligheder, og hvad der sker, hvis vi lukker for biltrafikken. Det kan eventuelt gøres med pullerter, der kan køres op og ned, så nødvendig beboer og varekørsel er mulig,« siger han.

Metin Aydin mener, at en undersøgelse skal vise, hvordan byrådet kan træffe en kvalificeret beslutning.

»Hvis vi skal gøre noget akut, kan det kun blive midlertidigt. Skal der for eksempel være plantekummer som tydeligt afgrænser vejen fra fortovet?« spørger han, der er uddannet arkitekt.

Socialdemokratiske Jesper Kjeldsen har aflagt et besøg i Vestergade, hvor han mødte Janni Gabriel og Katrine Vildlyng.

»Det er klart, at der skal være styr på skiltningen. Det er nok ikke i ond tro, at man kører de forkerte steder, eller at man kører den forkerte vej,« siger Jesper Kjeldsen, der i øvrigt mener, at Vestergade har fået en flot opgradering og er blevet smuk.

Men han ønsker ligesom sin radikale byrådskollega at få mere fakta og har is i maven, som han siger, til at se det an.

»Vi kan forstå, at ikke alle i erhvervslivet ønsker, at man lukker gaden for trafik. Og hvad sker der, hvis man gør det? Vi er forsigtigt positive over for at gøre noget ved trafikken. Vi er lydhøre og har brug for at få belyst emnet,« fortsætter Jesper Kjeldsen.

Når Aarhus Kommune ikke har plastret Vestergade til med tydelig skiltning, skyldes det, at man har en bevarende lokalplan og derfor ikke ønsker en skilteskov.

Både det radikale og det socialdemokratiske byrådsmedlem mener, at kommunen bør være fleksibel i forhold til det - i hvert fald i en periode

»Vi kan jo ikke have at folk kommer til skade. Det kunne måske løses med markeringer i vejbelægningen, der alligevel ikke er helt historisk autentisk, men en moderne og mere skridsikker form for brosten,« siger Metin Aydin.

»Vi har for nylig set en indretning af Sankt Pauls Kirkeplads, der var tænkt ud fra et æstetisk synspunkt, men som fik uheldige konsekvenser for en slagterbutiks varelevering. Sådan behøver det ikke at være. Man kan sagtens have æstetik for øje i byplanen, uden at det skal give en uheldig effekt for sikkerheden,« uddyber han.

Jesper Kjeldsen supplerer:

»I Jægergårdsgade har man valgt et midlertidigt skilt. Det kan man overveje også at gøre i Vestergade uden at vansire hele gaden. Så kan man opnå den ønskede æstetik på sigt.«

Byrådsmedlem Henrik Arens (LA) har i en artikel i Århus Stiftstidende foreslået at lukke for biltrafik i den del af Vestergade, hvor der er meget udeservering. Det er mellem Grønnegade og Vesterport.

Venstres Gert Bjerregaard er ikke enig, men foreslår en hastighedsbegrænsning på 20 eller 30 kilometer i timen - også for cykler og lommer til køretøjer, der afleverer varer.

»Vestergade er blevet en smutvej og man skal være varsom med bare at lukke torve og gader. Det er som vand, trafikken søger derhen, hvor det er nemmeste muligt. Det har konsekvenser, hver gang vi lukker noget som f.eks Vesterbro Torv,« siger han.

De personer i Vestergade, som avisen har snakket med, afviser dog, at der er plads til lommer til aflæsning.

Til det svarer Gert Bjerregaard:

»Det er en god idé at inddrage dem, der bor og arbejder i gaden, når løsningerne skal findes sammen med vores dygtige folk i Teknik og Miljø, så det bliver den bedste mulige version.«

Metin Aydin påpeger i øvrigt, at aarhusianerne må indse, at indre by på sigt skal friholdes for unødig trafik. Beboer- og varekørsel skal tillades, men folk udefra må parkere udenfor og gå ind, for hver gang byen vokser med 3.000 indbyggere, har de 1.000 biler med.

»Om cirka 10 år vil der være myldretrafik hele dagen, hvis vi ikke gør noget ved det, og så går byen til. Derfor må vi regulere på trafikken i midtbyen, der vil være præget af mindre trafik og flere oplevelser, specialbutikker, restauranter, caféer og vinbarer,« mener han.
eng_text:
In Vestergade in Aarhus, residents and business owners walk around with a stomach ache because they see dangerous traffic situations on their street every day.

“It’s only a matter of time before a really serious accident with the worst possible outcome happens. The other day, a pedestrian almost got run over because she didn’t look ahead when she stepped out into the street. She thought it was a pedestrian street. Afterwards, a parked van made a cyclist choose the sidewalk, where she couldn’t see a stroller with two people turning around the van and coming towards her. She had to brake very hard, and her heart was in her throat,” explains Janne Gabriel.

The newspaper has published photos and videos several times that document the major challenges on the street.

Business owners and residents have repeatedly explained that they experience mopeds milling through the street on the sidewalk, that garbage trucks torpedo cyclists and giant tourist buses that cannot get out of the narrow street. They fill the whole place when they reverse many times to get around corners and hit the furniture of the cafes - so far when there have been no people sitting in them.

Cars driving in the opposite direction also make it chaotic.

One wonders if they have all forgotten the traffic rules? But according to the street's traders, this is due to a lack of signage and that the new layout of the street is confusing.

Morten Skou Nicolaisen from Aarhus Municipality has received a number of inquiries and now says that the municipality is having an internal meeting next week about the situation in Vestergade with a view to possible further measures to prevent inappropriate road user behavior.

Radical Liberal Metin Aydin from Aarhus City Council has no doubt that something must be done in Vestergade.

"People's safety is so important that we must act on the situation. But we lack an analysis of the different options and what happens if we close the road to car traffic. This could possibly be done with bollards that can be moved up and down, so that necessary residents and goods traffic is possible," he says.

Metin Aydin believes that a study should show how the city council can make an informed decision.

"If we have to do something urgent, it can only be temporary. For example, should there be planters that clearly demarcate the road from the sidewalk?" he asks, who is a trained architect.

Social Democrat Jesper Kjeldsen has visited Vestergade, where he met Janni Gabriel and Katrine Vildlyng.

"It is clear that the signage must be in order. It's probably not in bad faith that people are driving in the wrong places or that they are driving in the wrong direction," says Jesper Kjeldsen, who also believes that Vestergade has been nicely upgraded and has become beautiful.

But like his radical city council colleague, he wants to get more facts and, as he says, has ice in his stomach to look at it.

"We can understand that not everyone in the business community wants the street to be closed to traffic. And what happens if you do? We are cautiously positive about doing something about the traffic. We are responsive and need to shed light on the issue," continues Jesper Kjeldsen.

When Aarhus Municipality has not plastered Vestergade with clear signage, it is because it has a conservation local plan and therefore does not want a forest of signs.

Both the Radical and the Social Democratic city council members believe that the municipality should be flexible in this regard - at least for a while

"We can't have people getting hurt. This could perhaps be solved with markings in the road surface, which is not entirely historically authentic anyway, but a modern and more non-slip form of cobblestone," says Metin Aydin.

"We recently saw a design of Sankt Pauls Kirkeplads that was designed from an aesthetic point of view, but which had unfortunate consequences for a butcher's shop's delivery of goods. It doesn't have to be that way. You can easily have aesthetics in mind in the city plan without it having an unfortunate effect on safety," he explains.

Jesper Kjeldsen adds:

"In Jægergårdsgade, a temporary sign has been chosen. You could also consider doing the same in Vestergade without disfiguring the entire street. Then you can achieve the desired aesthetics in the long term. ”

In an article in Århus Stiftstidende, city council member Henrik Arens (LA) has proposed closing the part of Vestergade where there is a lot of outdoor seating to car traffic. This is between Grønnegade and Vesterport.

The Liberal Party’s Gert Bjerregaard does not agree, but proposes a speed limit of 20 or 30 kilometers per hour - also for bicycles and pockets for vehicles delivering goods.

“Vestergade has become a shortcut and you have to be careful with just closing squares and streets. It’s like water, traffic seeks out where it’s easiest. It has consequences every time we close something like Vesterbro Torv,” he says.

However, the people in Vestergade that the newspaper has spoken to deny that there is room for pockets for reading.

To this, Gert Bjerregaard responds:

"It is a good idea to involve those who live and work in the street when finding solutions together with our skilled people in Engineering and Environment, so that it becomes the best possible version."

Metin Aydin also points out that the people of Aarhus must realize that in the long term the inner city must be kept free of unnecessary traffic. Residents and goods traffic must be allowed, but people from outside must park outside and walk in, because every time the city grows by 3,000 inhabitants, they have 1,000 cars with them.

"In about 10 years, there will be rush hour traffic all day long if we don't do something about it, and then the city will collapse. Therefore, we must regulate traffic in the city center, which will be characterized by less traffic and more experiences, specialty shops, restaurants, cafes and wine bars," he believes.

text:
Det er ikke blevet nemmere at være bilist i Aarhus midtby på den seneste. Flere afspærringer dukker op, hvilket kan gøre det mere besværligt at køre gennem byen.

Men nu kommer der et nyt initiativ fra Teknik og Miljø, som har til hensigt at gøre det nemmere at parkere i midtbyen.

Aarhus Kommune vil sætte nye digitale tavler op. Disse tavler skal guide bilister, så de kan nemt kan finde en parkeringsplads i midtbyen.

Det skriver Teknik og Miljø i en pressemeddelelse.

»Det skal være nemmere at finde en ledig parkeringsplads i Aarhus, og det bliver det med vores nye vejvisning,« siger rådmand for Teknik og Miljø Nicolaj Bang.

Der bliver i alt mere end 35 nye vejvisningstavler op i Aarhus.

Tavlerne er ifølge pressemeddelelsen det første synlige bevis på den grønne mobilitetsplan, som byrådet vedtog i juni.

»Vi kommer til at bruge tavlerne til at hjælpe bilisterne bedre gennem byen, når der for eksempel er kø efter et uheld eller i forbindelse med store vejarbejder,« siger Nicolaj Bang (K) og fortsætter:

»Jeg har ingen ambition om at jagte bilisterne ud af byen. Tavlerne er et signal om, at vi gerne vil gøre det lettere at være bilist i byen.«

De nye digitale tavler må som udgangspunkt kun vise trafikrelaterede budskaber. De må hverken vise reklamer eller videoer af nogen slags.

Venstre er imod mobilitetsplanen, men ser positivt på det nye forslag.

»Et rigtig flot forslag som Venstre har presset på for længe. Det vil helt sikkert gøre det nemmere at være bilist i Aarhus,« siger han og tilføjer:

»Desværre giver det ikke flere parkeringspladser i Aarhus midtby. I Venstre arbejder vi fortsat målrettet på at give aarhusianerne flere og bedre parkeringsmuligheder.«
eng_text:
It hasn't gotten any easier to be a driver in Aarhus city centre lately. More roadblocks are popping up, which can make it more difficult to drive through the city.

But now there's a new initiative from the Department of Technology and Environment, which aims to make parking in the city centre easier.

The Municipality of Aarhus will install new digital signs. These signs will guide drivers so that they can easily find a parking space in the city centre.

This is what the Department of Technology and Environment writes in a press release.

"It should be easier to find a free parking space in Aarhus, and that will be the case with our new signage," says Councillor for the Department of Technology and Environment Nicolaj Bang.

A total of more than 35 new signage signs will be installed in Aarhus.

According to the press release, the signs are the first visible evidence of the green mobility plan that the city council adopted in June.

"We will use the boards to help drivers better navigate the city when, for example, there is a queue after an accident or in connection with major road works," says Nicolaj Bang (K) and continues:

"I have no ambition to chase drivers out of the city. The boards are a signal that we want to make it easier to be a driver in the city."

The new digital boards may only display traffic-related messages as a general rule. They may not show advertisements or videos of any kind.

The Liberal Party is against the mobility plan, but views the new proposal positively.

"A really great proposal that the Liberal Party has been pushing for for too long. It will certainly make it easier to be a driver in Aarhus," he says and adds:

"Unfortunately, it does not provide more parking spaces in Aarhus city center. At the Liberal Party, we are continuing to work purposefully to give Aarhus residents more and better parking options."

text:
Skal bilerne have lov til at være i midtbyen eller ej? Det har mange en mening om, og skulle man være i tvivl, kan man blot tage et kig på seneste byrådsmøde, hvor debatten endnu en gang komme til at handle om det.

I juni trådte den grønne mobilitetsplan i kraft. Den består af 52 indsatser og dækker blandt andet konkrete anlægsprojekter, serviceopgraderinger, analyser og forsøg.

Formålet med mobilitetsplanen er, at 60 procent af transportbehovet i 2030 skal være dækket af cyklisme, kollektiv trafik eller gang. Ifølge planen skal parkeringsprincippet i midtbyen være, at længere besøg henvises til parkeringshuse, mens gadeparkering målrettes kortere besøg.

Nu har Moderaterne og Det Konservative Folkeparti stillet et forslag om, at de ønsker at halvere prisen på parkering i midtbyens kommunale parkeringshuse.

På byrådsmødet onsdag 27. august brugte byrådsmedlemmer lidt over en halv time på debatten om halvering af priserne. Flere af byrådspolitikerne ville gerne høres, og det endte derfor med at tage en del tid.

»Det er glædeligt, at der kommer et forslag, som vil forbedre forholdene for bilisterne i byen. Det manglede også bare, efter at man har hævet beboerparkeringen,« sagde Henrik Arens (LA).

Tilbage i vinters foreslog netop Liberal Alliance, at pladsen ved Bispetorv kunne bruges til midlertidige parkeringspladser. Dette forslag fik dog ikke stor nok opbakning i byrådet til at træde i kraft. Men på trods af det sagde Henrik Arrens (LA):

»Vi tager det ikke personligt i Liberal Alliance, og vi er glade for ønsket om at halvere priserne.«

Han pointerede, at det er ærgerligt, at aarhusianerne først ved, hvad der er op og ned efter valget. Det bliver først fremlagt til en politisk behandling af parkeringspolitikken i 2026.

Flere partier på venstrefløjen bakkede ikke op om forslaget.

»Vi mener, at forslaget er selvmodsigende. På den ene side hævder partierne, at billigere parkering i parkeringshusene vil støtte den grønne dagsorden. Samtidig siger de, at der forventes flere biler i byen med sådan et tiltag, hvilket er stik imod den grønne mobilitetsplan,« sagde Liv Gro Jensen (SF), og hun fik efterfølgende opbakning fra Radikale Venstre:

»Hvis vi sænker priserne på parkering, vil det lokke flere biler ind til byen. Men vi skal jo have færre biler indtil byen,« sagde Metin Aydin (RV) og fortsatte:

»Forslaget er et udtryk for politisk skizofreni. Uanset hvor nært kommunalvalget er, så kan Radikale Venstre ikke tiltræde.«

Polly Dutschke (M), der er en af dem bag forslaget, forsøgte at forsvare det.

»Billig parkering er ikke en modsætning til grøn politik. Tværtimod. Når vi styrer bilerne ind i parkeringshusene, så får vi færre biler i gaderne, mere plads til cykler, busser og byliv. Det er jo sund fornuft. Det er den vej vi skal gå,« sagde hun og fortsatte med hævet stemme:

»Vi døjer med trængsel. Det er den ene del af det. Den anden del handler om, hvordan vi får parkeringshusene til at fungere optimalt. Det er der flere nuancer i, det er jeg klar over. Men den eneste måde vi sikrer aarhusianerne i bymidten og i oplandet og giver de erhvervsdrivende en overlevelsesmulighed, så er vi nødt til at tænke tingene anderledes.«

Thure Hastrup (AL) sagde efterfølgende:

»Jeg tror ikke, at jeg behøver at hæve stemmen for at få argumenterne igennem. Når vi nu begynder at snakke om parkering i parkeringshuse, så har vi længe snakket om parker og rejs anlæg. Det skulle være et greb i den grønne mobilitetsplan. Hvad med at få det i gang?« spurgte han blandt andet.

Efter mange minutters debat tog rådmand for Teknik og Miljø, Nicolaj Bang (K), ordet:

»Tak for en lang debat. Jeg havde måske genovervejet at stille forslaget, hvis jeg havde vidst, at vi havde brugt så meget tid på at diskutere det. Det er altid interessant, hvordan folks ideologiske holdning kommer til udtryk, når der bliver talt om mobilitetsplanen,«

Han understregede, at der står i mobilitetsplanen, at det ønskes, at få flere biler ind i parkeringshuse og ikke nødvendigvis helt væk fra gaden.

Til slut fortalte han, at han er i gang med at undersøge, hvor der kan være flere korttidsparkeringspladser. I forhold til Bispetorvet er de i gang med at indrette torvet med bedre cykelparkering og skabe forudsætning for et levende torv.

I denne uge begynder de første forsøg med gratis transport ved Klokhøjen i Lisbjerg. Der er et letbanestop, hvor et forsøg bliver at give gratis transport med letbanen til de bilister, som parkerer der og rejser videre med letbanen.
eng_text:
Should cars be allowed in the city center or not? Many people have an opinion on this, and if you are in doubt, you can just take a look at the latest city council meeting, where the debate will once again be about it.

In June, the green mobility plan came into force. It consists of 52 initiatives and covers, among other things, specific construction projects, service upgrades, analyses and experiments.

The purpose of the mobility plan is that 60 percent of the transport need in 2030 should be covered by cycling, public transport or walking. According to the plan, the parking principle in the city center is that longer visits are referred to parking garages, while street parking is targeted at shorter visits.

Now, the Moderates and the Conservative People's Party have put forward a proposal that they want to halve the price of parking in the city center's municipal parking garages.

At the city council meeting on Wednesday, August 27, city council members spent just over half an hour debating halving the prices. Several of the city council politicians wanted to be heard, and it ended up taking quite some time.

“It is gratifying that there is a proposal that will improve conditions for drivers in the city. It was also just missing after the increase in resident parking,” said Henrik Arens (LA).

Back in the winter, the Liberal Alliance proposed that the space at Bispetorv could be used for temporary parking spaces. However, this proposal did not receive enough support in the city council to come into effect. Despite this, Henrik Arrens (LA) said:

“We do not take it personally in the Liberal Alliance, and we are happy about the desire to halve the prices.”

He pointed out that it is a pity that the people of Aarhus will only know what is up and down after the election. It will not be presented for a political discussion of the parking policy in 2026.

Several parties on the left did not support the proposal.

“We believe that the proposal is contradictory. On the one hand, the parties claim that cheaper parking in the parking garages will support the green agenda. At the same time, they say that more cars are expected in the city with such an initiative, which is directly against the green mobility plan," said Liv Gro Jensen (SF), and she subsequently received support from the Radical Left:

"If we lower the prices for parking, it will lure more cars into the city. But we must have fewer cars until the city," said Metin Aydin (RV) and continued:

"The proposal is an expression of political schizophrenia. No matter how close the municipal elections are, the Radical Left cannot take office."

Polly Dutschke (M), who is one of those behind the proposal, tried to defend it.

"Cheap parking is not the opposite of green policy. On the contrary. When we direct the cars into the parking garages, we get fewer cars on the streets, more space for bicycles, buses and city life. It's common sense. That's the way we need to go," she said and continued in a raised voice:

"We suffer from congestion. That's one part of it. The other part is about how we make the parking garages function optimally. There are several nuances to that, I'm aware of that. But the only way we can secure the Aarhusians in the city center and in the surrounding area and give businesses a chance to survive is if we think about things differently."

Thure Hastrup (AL) then said:

"I don't think I need to raise my voice to get the arguments across. When we start talking about parking in parking garages, we've been talking about parks and ride facilities for a long time. That should be a measure in the green mobility plan. How about getting it started?" he asked, among other things.

After many minutes of debate, Councilor for Technology and Environment, Nicolaj Bang (K), took the floor:

"Thank you for a long debate. I might have reconsidered making the proposal if I had known that we had spent so much time discussing it. It is always interesting how people's ideological positions are expressed when talking about the mobility plan,"

He emphasized that the mobility plan states that it is desired to get more cars into parking garages and not necessarily completely off the street.

Finally, he said that he is currently investigating where there could be more short-term parking spaces. In relation to Bispetorvet, they are currently designing the square with better bicycle parking and creating the conditions for a vibrant square.

This week, the first trials with free transport will begin at Klokhøjen in Lisbjerg. There is a light rail stop, where an attempt will be made to provide free transport with the light rail to those drivers who park there and travel on with the light rail.

text:
Det er mest princippet i det, der giver Rita Laustsen en øv-følelse.

Medejeren af den kendte Restaurant Kohalen i Sydhavnen i Aarhus har netop fået en skrivelse om, at restauranten mister 10 ud af de 20 p-pladser. Det er p-pladser, restauranten betaler for, og som har tilhørt det historiske spisested i 30 år.

P-pladserne, der bliver inddraget, skal i stedet bruges af bilister, der skulle have parkeret i et parkeringshus ved Kulkransportet. Konstruktionen af p-huset, som Aarhus Kommune er ansvarlig for, er dog blevet forsinket.

I stedet får Restaurant Kohalen nogle parkeringspladser nær restauranten med indkørsel direkte fra Jægergårdsgade. På sigt skal restaurantens gæster formentlig parkere i det kommende p-hus.

»Vi har haft p-pladserne i 30 år, og det er et stort privilegium for os at have de pladser. Vi har mange stamgæster, der er vant til at parkere her, og de siger tit, at det er så dejligt, at de kan det,« siger Rita Laustsen og fortsætter:

»Jeg kan blive bange for, at folk ikke kommer på samme måde, som de altid har gjort, fordi de ikke kan få en p-plads her. Jeg er bekymret for, at det kan gå ud over bundlinjen. Jeg synes, det er uartigt, at man bare kommer og tager pladserne.«

De p-pladser, kommunen har tilbudt Restaurant Kohalen, ligger få meter fra de eksisterende, der er placeret direkte foran indgangen til restauranten. De ”nye” p-pladser er ikke i så god stand som de eksisterende.

Det er Aarhus Ejendomme hos Aarhus Kommune, der har valgt, at netop Restaurant Kohalen får inddraget 10 af sine 20 p-pladser. Ifølge fuldmægtig Palle Schmidt, der arbejder med udlejning og administration af erhvervslejemål, er det uklart, om restauranten kan få sine p-pladser tilbage, når p-huset står færdigt.

»De vil ikke blive flyttet til p-huset, men i det samme område som nu. Om det bliver præcis de samme pladser som i dag, kan vi ikke svare på,« lyder det.

Rita Laustsen, er det ikke lidt forkælet at brokke sig over, at restaurantens p-pladser flyttes, når der bare er tale om ret få meter?

»Jeg ved ikke, om det er forkælet. P-pladserne har hørt til Kohalen fra starten. Jeg synes, kommunen skal vente med at tage vores pladser, til p-huset er færdigt. Det er dem, der er forsinkede med et projekt. Hvorfor kan de bare tage vores pladser fra os? Det er som om, vi er mindre vigtige, og det synes jeg er øv.«

Som bystrategisk chef ved Teknik og Miljø hos Aarhus Kommune har Bente Lykke Sørensen det overordnede ansvar for det nye p-hus i Sydhavnen. Ifølge hende handler forsinkelsen om, at det vindende projekt i en arkitektkonkurrence af forskellige årsager ikke kunne realiseres.

»Ifølge planerne skulle p-huset have stået færdigt, når lejerne skulle bruge det. Det er der nu fundet en løsning på, hvor lejerne tilbydes overfladeparkering ved det gamle slagterområde. Jeg erkender til fulde, at ansvaret for p-huset ligger hos mig. Det projekt, vi har i dag, er ikke forsinket, og vi forventer, at det er færdigt i oktober 2026,« siger hun.

Udover Restaurant Kohalen får blandt andre også virksomhederne Tiny Office og Akustikken inddraget deres nuværende p-pladser.

Restaurant Kohalen er en af Aarhus’ ældste restauranter og kan føre sin historie helt tilbage til 1907. Restauranten serverer klassisk dansk mad. I januar 2025 vandt de, ikke for første gang, prisen for Danmarks Bedste Bøfsandwich.
eng_text:
It is mostly the principle of what gives Rita Laustsen a sense of accomplishment.

The co-owner of the well-known Restaurant Kohalen in Sydhavnen in Aarhus has just received a letter stating that the restaurant will lose 10 out of the 20 parking spaces. These are parking spaces that the restaurant pays for and that have belonged to the historic eatery for 30 years.

The parking spaces that will be withdrawn will instead be used by drivers who should have parked in a parking garage at Kulkransportet. The construction of the parking garage, for which Aarhus Municipality is responsible, has been delayed, however.

Instead, Restaurant Kohalen will get some parking spaces near the restaurant with a driveway directly from Jægergårdsgade. In the long term, the restaurant's guests will probably have to park in the upcoming parking garage.

"We have had the parking spaces for 30 years, and it is a great privilege for us to have those spaces. We have many regulars who are used to parking here, and they often say that it is so nice that they can do it,” says Rita Laustsen and continues:

“I can be afraid that people will not come in the same way they always have because they cannot get a parking space here. I am worried that it may affect the bottom line. I think it is rude that people just come and take the spaces.”

The parking spaces that the municipality has offered Restaurant Kohalen are located a few meters from the existing ones, which are located directly in front of the entrance to the restaurant. The “new” parking spaces are not in as good condition as the existing ones.

It is Aarhus Ejendomme at Aarhus Municipality that has chosen that Restaurant Kohalen will have 10 of its 20 parking spaces withdrawn. According to manager Palle Schmidt, who works with the rental and administration of commercial leases, it is unclear whether the restaurant will be able to get its parking spaces back when the parking garage is finished.

"They will not be moved to the parking garage, but in the same area as now. Whether it will be exactly the same spaces as today, we cannot answer," it says.

Rita Laustsen, isn't it a bit spoiled to complain about the restaurant's parking spaces being moved, when it is only a matter of a few meters?

"I don't know if it is spoiled. The parking spaces have belonged to Kohalen from the beginning. I think the municipality should wait to take our spaces until the parking garage is finished. They are the ones who are late with a project. Why can they just take our spaces from us? It is as if we are less important, and I think that is a shame."

As urban strategy manager at Technology and Environment at Aarhus Municipality, Bente Lykke Sørensen has overall responsibility for the new parking garage in Sydhavnen. According to her, the delay is because the winning project in an architectural competition could not be realized for various reasons.

"According to the plans, the parking garage should have been finished when the tenants needed it. A solution has now been found, where the tenants are offered surface parking at the old butcher's area. I fully acknowledge that the responsibility for the parking garage lies with me. The project we have today has not been delayed, and we expect it to be completed in October 2026," she says.

In addition to Restaurant Kohalen, the companies Tiny Office and Akustikken, among others, will also have their current parking spaces withdrawn.

Restaurant Kohalen is one of Aarhus' oldest restaurants and can trace its history back to 1907. The restaurant serves classic Danish food. In January 2025, they won, not for the first time, the award for Denmark's Best Steak Sandwich.

text:
Iført gule veste og hjelme stod et hav af håndværkere mandag 10. november i kø for at få en gratis pølse på en byggeplads ved Sydhavnen.

Bag skranken stod en ikke hvilken som helst pølsemand. Spidskandidat for Venstre Aarhus, Christian Budde (V), langede pølser og brød over disken med et glimt i øjet til de sultne håndværkere.

»Skal det være med det hele,« spurgte Christian Budde (V).

»Bare ketchup og remoulade, tak,« svarede en af de mange sultne håndværkere, der var nået forrest i den lange kø.

Som optakt til kommunalvalget havde Venstre Aarhus besluttet at invitere til »Brokkedag for håndværkere.« Formanden havde blandt andet hørt håndværkerforeningen beskrive parkeringsforholdene som krigslignende tilstande. Håndværkerne beskrev, at de har problemer med at få afleveret varer og parkere deres bil.

»Fremfor at handle på synsninger tager vi ned i dag, hvor jeg tror, at vi ender med at tale med et par hundrede. Så får de en pølse som tak for, at de gør os lidt klogere,« sagde Christian Budde (V).

Avisen adspurgte flere af de fremmødte, og mange af dem var utilfredse med parkering. Emil Andreas Vestergaard var en af dem.

Han er elektrikerlærling ved Stilling Køl og El og tager toget på arbejde, fordi han har fået at vide, at han aldrig kan være garanteret en parkeringsplads. Men når han tager offentlig transport, er det heller ikke uden problemer.

»Jeg har to gange misset toget, fordi de var overfyldte,« sagde Emil Andreas Vestergaard.

De overfyldte tog skyldes, at Banedanmark er ved at lave nogle af sporene om og gøre dem klar til de nye eltog. Det betyder, at passagerer kun kan rejse fra spor 2 og 3.

Hvis han alligevel har forsøgt at tage bilen til arbejdet i midtbyen, har det været umuligt for ham at finde en parkeringsplads tæt på. Det kan betyde, at han allerede er øm, inden arbejdsdagen for alvor går i gang, fordi han skal slæbe sin tunge værktøjskasse.

»Hvis man gerne vil have bygget eller lavet noget, så skal der også være plads til, at vi kan komme herud,« sagde han.

Det findes ikke mange mennesker, som vil sige nej til gratis mad. Slet ikke de fremmødte håndværkere, og flere så sit snit til at få anden runde. Solen skinnede fra en skyfri himmel på de hårdtarbejdende, der nød en velfortjent frokostpause.

»De har fanget håndværkerne det rigtige sted. Vi kan jo godt lide gratis mad, det er ikke nogen hemmelighed,« sagde tømrer August Kjeldberg med et smil på læben.

Han var enig i at finde en parkeringsplads til dagligt kan være svært.

»Lige nu parkerer vi halvanden kilometer væk og går resten af vejen med 40 kilo værktøj. Der er ikke plads til os. Det er ganske enkelt. Jeg tænker klart, at politikerne bør sikre flere parkeringspladser til os,« sagde han.

Den næste trådte frem i frokostkøen. Det var elektrikeren Justin Abraham, og han var enig i, at parkering er et problem.

»Jeg har virkelig haft problemer med at finde en parkeringsplads her i centrum,« sagde han.

Udover parkering havde han dog andet at påpege.

»Jeg vil gøre noget ved arbejdsmiljøet. Der skal være mere samvær. Der skal være plads til at fejle, og vi skal ikke være så hårde ved hinanden.«

I 2023 oprettede Aarhus Kommune 74 håndværkerparkeringspladser, der er øremærket til erhvervsbiler på gule plader i en forsøgsordning. Venstre vil gerne fordoble antallet af denne type parkeringspladser.

»Det er vigtigt for Venstre, at vi får at vide, hvor skoen trykker. Det er de her mennesker, som er en del af vores hverdag. De bygger og udvikler Aarhus,« sagde Gert Bjerregaard, der ved brokkedagen var blevet bekræftet i, at håndværkerne mangler parkering.

Efter lidt over en times servering af pølser og brød, trådte Christian Budde (V) ud af pølsevognen og blev samlet med de øvrige medlemmer af Venstre Aarhus.

»Jeg regner med, at vi inden for så mange dage kommer til at tage en snak med andre borgere om trafikken, hvor vi kommer til at servere noget andet end pølser. Vi kan se, at ”Vi vil have Aarhus” tilbage kampagnen interesserer mange mennesker,« sagde spidskandidaten.
eng_text:
Wearing yellow vests and helmets, a sea of craftsmen stood in line on Monday, November 10, to get a free sausage at a construction site by Sydhavnen.

Behind the counter stood not just any sausage man. The leading candidate for Venstre Aarhus, Christian Budde (V), passed sausages and bread over the counter with a twinkle in his eye to the hungry craftsmen.

“Is that all?” asked Christian Budde (V).

“Just ketchup and remoulade, please,” replied one of the many hungry craftsmen who had reached the front of the long queue.

As a prelude to the municipal elections, Venstre Aarhus had decided to invite to a “Brocked Day for Craftsmen.” Among other things, the chairman had heard the craftsman association describe the parking conditions as war-like conditions. The craftsmen described that they have problems delivering goods and parking their cars.

"Rather than acting on opinions, we're going down today, where I think we'll end up talking to a couple of hundred. Then they'll get a sausage as a thank you for making us a little smarter," said Christian Budde (V).

The newspaper interviewed several of those present, and many of them were dissatisfied with parking. Emil Andreas Vestergaard was one of them.

He is an electrician's apprentice at Stilling Køl og El and takes the train to work because he has been told that he can never be guaranteed a parking space. But when he takes public transport, it's not without problems either.

"I've missed the train twice because they were overcrowded," said Emil Andreas Vestergaard.

The overcrowded trains are because Banedanmark is in the process of redoing some of the tracks and preparing them for the new electric trains. This means that passengers can only travel from tracks 2 and 3.

If he has tried to take his car to work in the city centre, it has been impossible for him to find a parking space close by. This could mean that he is already sore before the workday really starts, because he has to lug his heavy toolbox.

“If you want to build or make something, there must also be room for us to get out here,” he said.

There are not many people who would say no to free food. Not at all the tradesmen who were present, and several saw their cut to get a second round. The sun shone from a cloudless sky on the hardworking people who were enjoying a well-deserved lunch break.

“They have caught the tradesmen in the right place. We like free food, that's no secret,” said carpenter August Kjeldberg with a smile on his face.

He agreed that finding a parking space on a daily basis can be difficult.

“Right now we park a kilometer and a half away and walk the rest of the way with 40 kilos of tools. There is no room for us. It is quite simple. I clearly think that the politicians should ensure more parking spaces for us,” he said.

The next person in the lunch queue stepped forward. It was electrician Justin Abraham, and he agreed that parking is a problem.

“I have really had trouble finding a parking space here in the city center,” he said.

In addition to parking, however, he had something else to point out.

“I want to do something about the working environment. There needs to be more togetherness. There needs to be room to make mistakes, and we shouldn’t be so hard on each other.”

In 2023, Aarhus Municipality created 74 craftsman parking spaces, which are earmarked for commercial vehicles with yellow plates in a pilot scheme. The Liberal Party wants to double the number of this type of parking spaces.

“It is important for the Liberal Party that we are told where the shoe is pinching. These are the people who are part of our everyday lives. They build and develop Aarhus," said Gert Bjerregaard, who had been confirmed at the protest day that the craftsmen lack parking.

After a little over an hour of serving sausages and bread, Christian Budde (V) stepped out of the hot dog cart and was gathered with the other members of Venstre Aarhus.

"I expect that within so many days we will have a talk with other citizens about traffic, where we will serve something other than sausages. We can see that the "We want Aarhus back" campaign interests many people," said the lead candidate.

text:
Det kan betale sig at henvende sig til medierne.

Det gælder i hvert fald tilfældet Rita Laustsen. Hun er medejer af Restaurant Kohalen, og hun kontaktede for nylig dette medie, fordi hun følte sig uretfærdigt behandlet af Aarhus Kommune.

Rita Laustsen var blevet meddelt, at kommunen ved årsskiftet ville inddrage 10 af restaurantens 20 p-pladser. P-pladser, restauranten betaler for, og som har tilhørt det historiske spisested i Sydhavnen i 30 år. P-pladserne skulle, oplyste kommunen, bruges af bilister, der mangler en p-plads, fordi et parkeringshus ved Kulkransportet er blevet forsinket. Det er Aarhus Kommune, der er ansvarlig for at bygge p-huset.

Nu har rådmanden for Teknik og Miljø i Aarhus Kommune, Nicolaj Bang (K), omgjort beslutningen, oplyser hans partikollega og medlem af Aarhus Byråd, Bünyamin Simsek.

»Jeg er gået ind i sagen, fordi Kohalen er en institution i Aarhus, og ejerne skal ikke bøde for, at et p-hus er forsinket. Mobilitetsafdelingen, der står for planlægningen af det her, har ikke haft en dialog med de forretningsdrivende i området. Rita oplevede, at hun ikke blev lyttet til, men bare fik at vide, hvordan det skulle være. Det er vi blevet opmærksomme på, fordi dit medie har skrevet om sagen, og nu har rådmanden sat en retning for, hvordan det skal løses,« siger Bünyamin Simsek.

Restaurant Kohalen, der serverer klassisk dansk mad, er en af Aarhus’ ældste restauranter og kan føre sin historie helt tilbage til 1907.

Indtil rådmanden gik ind i sagen, var planen, at Restaurant Kohalen i stedet for de nuværende ville få nogle parkeringspladser nær restauranten med indkørsel direkte fra Jægergårdsgade. Det var uklart, om restauranten på sigt kunne få sine p-pladser tilbage.

Bünyamin Simsek, er læren, at man bare skal henvende sig til medierne, hvis man føler sig uretfærdigt behandlet, og så kommer der en rådmand og ændrer det, man er utilfreds med?

»Nej, man skal henvende sig til rådmanden. Det er vigtigt, at embedsmændene ikke bare sidder og træffer beslutninger ved skrivebordet. Det er netop det, der er problemet, og det er derfor, der oprettes et detailråd. Vi bliver nødt til at tage dialogen, så de forretningsdrivende kan komme ind i loopet, og så kan det godt være, det ikke bliver én til én, som de ønsker det, men det er vigtigt, at de bliver hørt og inddraget i planlægningsprocessen. I det her tilfælde var den lille restauratør kommet i klemme. Den lille restauratør er blevet hørt og lyttet til nu, og rådmanden har rullet beslutningen tilbage.«

Nicolaj Bang har i sin tid som rådmand rullet flere beslutninger tilbage, fx da han sidste år genåbnede det meste af Vesterbro Torv for biler kort tid efter, torvet var blevet ensrettet. Er det nødvendigvis en god ting, at man bare skifter kurs, hvis noget driller?

»Det ved jeg godt, er der forskellige holdninger til, men jeg synes, det er fornuftigt, at han er villig til at bakke. Det viser, at han er villig til at lytte, for nogle gange er teori og praksis ikke det samme. Vi har nogle rigtig dygtige fagfolk, der træffer nogle beslutninger ud fra stor viden, men nogle gange, når man implementerer noget, bliver resultatet ikke som i teorien, og så er det vigtigt, at man kan rulle en beslutning tilbage.«

Det har dags dato ikke været muligt at få en kommentar fra Rita Laustsen.

Detailrådet, Bünyamin Simsek refererer til, er endnu ikke blevet vedtaget i byrådet. Rådet er del af et forslag om at sikre detailhandlens fremtid, som Socialdemokratiet, SF, Konservative og Danmarksdemokraterne står bag. Forslaget er aktuelt til behandling i Teknik og Miljø, efter at det blev taget varmt imod på et byrådsmøde. Detailrådet skal, såfremt det bliver vedtaget, fungere som et bindeled mellem kommune og butikker, og idéen er, at rådet skal konsulteres, når politikerne overvejer ændringer, som påvirker handelslivet.
eng_text:
It pays to contact the media.

At least that is the case with Rita Laustsen. She is a co-owner of Restaurant Kohalen, and she recently contacted this media outlet because she felt unfairly treated by Aarhus Municipality.

Rita Laustsen had been informed that the municipality would take away 10 of the restaurant's 20 parking spaces at the turn of the year. Parking spaces that the restaurant pays for and that have belonged to the historic eatery in Sydhavnen for 30 years. The parking spaces, the municipality stated, were to be used by drivers who lack a parking space because a parking garage at Kulkransportet has been delayed. Aarhus Municipality is responsible for building the parking garage.

Now the councilor for Technology and Environment in Aarhus Municipality, Nicolaj Bang (K), has reversed the decision, according to his party colleague and member of Aarhus City Council, Bünyamin Simsek.

"I have become involved in the matter because Kohalen is an institution in Aarhus, and the owners should not be fined for a parking garage being delayed. The mobility department, which is responsible for planning this, has not had a dialogue with the business owners in the area. Rita felt that she was not listened to, but was only told how it should be. We became aware of this because your media wrote about the matter, and now the councilor has set a direction for how it should be resolved," says Bünyamin Simsek.

Restaurant Kohalen, which serves classic Danish food, is one of Aarhus' oldest restaurants and can trace its history all the way back to 1907.

Until the councilor became involved in the matter, the plan was that Restaurant Kohalen would get some parking spaces near the restaurant instead of the current ones with a driveway directly from Jægergårdsgade. It was unclear whether the restaurant would be able to get its parking spaces back in the long term.

Bünyamin Simsek, is the lesson that you should just go to the media if you feel you are being treated unfairly, and then a councillor will come and change what you are unhappy with?

»No, you should go to the councillor. It is important that the officials do not just sit at their desks and make decisions. That is precisely the problem, and that is why a retail council is being set up. We need to start a dialogue so that the business owners can get into the loop, and it may not be one-on-one as they would like, but it is important that they are heard and included in the planning process. In this case, the small restaurateur was in a bind. The small restaurateur has been heard and listened to now, and the councilor has rolled back the decision. 

Nicolaj Bang has rolled back several decisions during his time as councilor, for example when he reopened most of Vesterbro Torv to cars last year shortly after the square had become one-way. Is it necessarily a good thing to just change course if something is bothering you? 

"I know there are different opinions on that, but I think it makes sense that he is willing to back down. It shows that he is willing to listen, because sometimes theory and practice are not the same. We have some really skilled professionals who make decisions based on great knowledge, but sometimes when you implement something, the result is not as in theory, and then it is important that you can roll back a decision." 

It has not been possible to get a comment from Rita Laustsen to date. 

The retail council, to which Bünyamin Simsek refers, has not yet been adopted by the city council. The council is part of a proposal to secure the future of retail, which is supported by the Social Democrats, the Socialist Party, the Conservative Party and the Danish Democrats. The proposal is currently being considered in the Technical and Environmental Affairs Committee, after it was warmly welcomed at a city council meeting. If adopted, the retail council will function as a link between the municipality and shops, and the idea is that the council will be consulted when politicians consider changes that affect retail.
